Best Black Friday 2016 Deals on Drones http://bit.ly/2ff8oe4   A new generation of professional drones with foldable wings took flight in 2016, pushing the prices down of conventional drones. Here are the best Black Friday drone deals. As part of our annual Top 100 Black Friday 2016 Deals we analyzed Black Friday 2016 ads to find the best deals on drones. In 2016 DJI and GoPro introduced new professional drones with the DJI Mavic drone and the GoPro Karma that are much more portable than the previous generations. The wings on the Karma and the Mavic can be folded. This is a feature small pocket drones like the Dobby or Hover camera introduced. Don't Miss: Best Walmart Black Friday 2016 Deals There are no Black Friday deals on the DJI Mavic, due to supply issues. The GoPro Karma has been recently recalled. Retailers have advertised deals on the DJI drone that made the Chinese drone maker the world's number 1. The DJI Phantom drones are advertised in the Walmart, Target and Best Buy Black Friday ad. See the Black Friday DJI Phantom drone deals listed below. The Walmart Black Friday DJI Phantom deal is the best, priced at $369. Black Friday DJI Drone Deals $369 DJI Phantom 3 Standard - Walmart $399.99 DJI Phantom 3 Standard - Target $799.99 DJI Phantom 3 Professional - Best Buy $999.99 DJI Pantom 4 - Best Buy Find all current DJI Phantom deals on amazon.com. Besides the above deals on a semi-professional drone, Black Friday ads feature plenty of deals on smaller drones and on toy drones. The list below features the best drone deals in that category. [Poll] SUBSCRIBE Full RSS Feed Latest News Feed Entertainment News Feed Tech Feed World News Gaming Feed Sports Feed Funny & Strange Feed Health Feed Lifestyle Feed BuzzWorthy Feed Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Delivered To Your INBOX Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Email Address Or follow us online Facebook Twitter Google-plus Rss Black Friday 2016 Ads: Where To Find The Best Video Game And Electronics Deals From Target, Walmart, Best Buy, And More Shopping 3 0 0 November 19, 2016 Black Friday 2016 Ads: Where To Find The Best Video Game And Electronics Deals From Target, Walmart, Best Buy, And More Nathan Francis Black Friday 2016 is almost here, and shoppers looking to find the best deals on electronics and video games from places like Target, Best Buy, and Walmart may find it a bit difficult to navigate through all the ads. Black Friday deals have a tendency to repeat themselves, so three or four major retailers may offer nearly identical deals on video game bundles or flat-screen televisions. Figuring out which store really has the best deals can take a lot of work, but below you can find a list of the top deals on video games and electronics along with the best offerings from some of the major Black Friday destinations. With all deals once exclusive to Black Friday now spreading out across the month of November and also beyond Thanksgiving, there is some worry among consumers that the best deals may not actually be on Black Friday. NerdWallet’s 2016 Consumer Holiday Shopping Report found that’s a concern of two in three shoppers. But as Fortune noted, those fears can be put to rest — the best sales this holiday shopping season will indeed be on Black Friday 2016. “NerdWallet’s analysis of ads from retailers, however, shows there’s no reason to fear that you’ll miss out,” the report noted. “Major stores, such as Kohl’s, JCPenney, Best Buy, Kmart and Sears, truly are offering better prices on Black Friday than on other November sales.” Best Black Friday 2016 video game deals Shoppes looking for deals on video games and systems like the Xbox One or Playstation 4 Slim or 4 Pro will have a lot of deals to sift through.Virtually every retailer is offering bundles with systems and video games together, and many of those deals look nearly identical. Shoppers looking for Playstation deals can look through a complete list from CNet. The highlights include a PS4 Slim Uncharted Bundle for $250 at Walmart along with a $30 gift card. For those not into console gaming, PC Gamer is putting together a list of the best PC gaming deals on Black Friday. Best Black Friday 2016 deals on electronics Black Friday is one of the most popular times to snag deals on flat-screen televisions, tablets, cell phones, and other electronic accessories. Consumer Reports has compiled a list of the best deals on televisions, which includes: 43-inch Element ELEFW408 4K UHD TV, $125, at Target 49-inch Toshiba 4K smart TV, $200, at Best Buy 60-inch Vizio 1080p smart TV, $300, at Walmart Tablets and cell phones are also a popular pick, and Network World has a list of the best deals on Android devices and Fortune has a list of the best ones from Apple — which includes a $250 gift card from Walmart with the purchase of any iPhone and a $125 discount on iPad Air 2 and iPad Pro models at Best Buy. Best Black Friday 2016 deals at Walmart Forbes has done an excellent store-by-store rundown of all the Black Friday 2016 deals, and has some warnings about deals to avoid at Walmart. The stores will be offering some of the best prices on flat-screen televisions, but buyers should beware that they aren’t the highest quality models. THE WALMART BLACK FRIDAY AD IS HERE! https://t.co/4mWGjY8H2N pic.twitter.com/xNYF9M35yf — Black Friday Ads (@BFAds) November 10, 2016 “Regarding Element and Hisense, these are budget TVs so don’t expect world class quality but the cost for the size beats every other retailer this Black Friday,” the report noted. Here are some of the best deals from Forbes. Samsung Galaxy S6 on Straight Talk Wireless + Straight Talk Wireless $55/30 Day Unlimited Talk, Text and Data Plan Card for $249 (save $150) PlayStation 4 Slim Uncharted 4 500GB Bundle w/ $30 Gift Card for $249 (save $50) Element or Hisense (by location) 40-inch HDTV for $125 Best Black Friday 2016 deals at Best Buy For everything electronics, it’s often hard to beat the variety and prices found at Best Buy. Here are some of the best deals (via Forbes). HP 15.6″ Laptop w/ AMD A6-7310, 4GB RAM, 500GB (15-BA009DX) for $169.99 (save $90) Any iPhone 7 Device — Get up to a $250 Best Buy Gift Card with installment billing agreement with Verizon, Sprint, and AT&T. Samsung Galaxy S7 or S7 Edge + Samsung Gear VR + $50 Oculus Content Pack + $250 Gift Card w/Installment Billing Agent for Verizon, Sprint, and AT&T iPad Air 2 (All Models) for $125 Off Microsoft 12.3″ Surface Pro 4 Bundle with Signature Type Cover for $599.99 (save $400) – an in store doorbuster For shoppers looking to make Best Buy a destination on Black Friday, Forbes has a breakdown of what to look for and what to avoid. It’s not #BlackFriday yet, but the deals from our ad couldn’t wait. #GiftingMadeEasy https://t.co/UXOuZpjsCE — Best Buy (@BestBuy) November 10, 2016 Best Black Friday 2016 deals at Target Target is once again one of the leaders among Black Friday destinations, and the deals extend beyond the traditional electronics and clothing. The store is offering a $150 discount on the Dyson Ball Origin Upright Vacuum. For the photography enthusiast, there’s a $300 discount on the Canon DSLR EOS T6 Bundle. For a full list of the best Black Friday 2016 deals at Target, check out this review from The Huffington Post. Other Black Friday 2016 deals For those looking for something beyond video game and electronics on Black Friday 2016, Glamour has compiled a list of all the best deals on designer clothing. Sportsmans Guide is also putting together a list of the top Black Friday deals on outdoor gear. A full list of ads from all retailers on Black Friday 2016 can be found at NerdWallet. It's On MyTV Everything on TV Menu Skip to content Breaking News Sports NFL MLB NBA COLLEGE Football NHL Boxing NCAAB PGA Tennis SOCCER Reality TV Technology World Search for: WALMART 2016 Black Friday Online Deals, early bird specials: Doorbusters, Wal-mart app, free shipping November 19, 2016Business and Shoppingwalmart 2016 ads, walmart ads released, walmart black friday, walmart black friday ad, walmart black friday ads, walmart black friday deals, walmart black friday leaked ads, walmart doorbuster deals, walmart iphone 7, walmart iphone deals, walmart opening hours, walmart thanksgivingClay Hayes   Shoppers can now avail Black Friday deals online at Walmart with free shipping. With thousands of products available for the biggest shopping event of the year, Walmart will not run out of surprises. Walmart Black Friday 2016 ad is finally here. We are now less than a week away from Black Friday, and the buzz for shopping is going on a high note with each day passing by. After electronic deals, more and more people are looking to grab great deal on Apparel and Home electronics. While many retailers only have discounted deals on few particular items, Walmart 2016 Black Friday ads can be of huge savings on all products. Walmart Black Friday deals online begin on Thanksgiving Thursday at 12AM and In-store deals open at 6PM on same day – 24th November. Like every year few stores will be offering wristbands for customer’s hassle-free shopping and also there are some special discounted deals offered for people having Walmart App, all app orders will be shipped at home– go ahead download it for free! We already love what Walmart is offering on electronic and mobile deal such as Philips 55″ 4K UHDTV at $298, Xbox/PS4 at just $27 and $250 worth Gift Card on Apple’s iPhone 7 with installment billing agreement from AT&T, Sprint or Verizon. Let’s see the offers coming from Walmart on Black Friday on Apparel and Home Electronics. Walmart Black Friday Deals on Kids/Women apparel Choice of sleepwear should be important, as having relaxing bedtime helps overall mental and physical development. If you are looking to comfort your child with soft and cozy sleepwear then you should consider Walmart’s range of sleepwear for children. Toddler’s parents can buy Infant/Toddler 2-pc. Character Cotton Sleepwear Set (Assorted) or Kids Healthtex 2-pc. Fleece Sleapwear Set (Assorted) both offered at $4.75 each. For boys and girls sized 4 to 16 can go with these vibrant options – Boys 2-pc. Character Sleep Set (Assorted Styles) or Girls 2-pc. Character Sleep Set (Assorted) all at $4.75 each. Kids Character Slippers (Assorted) are also available at $4.75. Under special buy Walmart has Boys or Girls 1-pc. Character Sleepwear (Assorted Styles) priced at $8.50 and Faded Glory Boys Orange 1/4-Zip Fleece Hoodie can be purchased at $4.75 only. Walmart Black Friday is also offering Character Backpack (Assorted Styles) for children at $5.50 only. Wrangler Boys Straight Jeans are now cheaper with Walmart deals, get them at $8.50. Ladies throw all your old and boring sleepwear and winter wear, because Walmart Black Friday deals can prove beneficial for you. Buy Union Suit Womens Sleepwear (Assorted Colors) and Womens 2-pc. Character Sleep Set (Assorted Colors) at just $9 each. The very stylish Cuddl Duds Womens Climate Right 2-pc. Thermal Set (Assorted Colors) can be availed at $9, also save $6 on Riders by Lee Womens Fleece-Lined Shirt (Assorted Colors) offered now at $9. For warp lovers, Walmart has Womens Character Cozy Wrap (Assorted) priced at $9. Complete your shopping by getting the right apparel match, you can buy funky looking Womens Novelty Character Slippers (Assorted) and colourful Womens Fleece-Lined Leggings (2-pk.) at special price of $7 each. Womens Cozy Fleece Sleep Pants (Assorted Designs) and Womens Muk Luks Cozy Slipper Socks (Assorted Designs) both are offered $4.50 each. Also be winter ready with Womens Knee-High Socks (Assorted) offered at $4.50 only. If you love Emoji Beanies don’t forget to buy them at $3. Hawaii Opinion Editorials Letters Op-Eds Kate Riley Mark Higgins Brier Dudley Jonathan Martin Thanh Tan Blanca Torres Columnists Nicole Brodeur FYI Guy Mary Ann Gwinn Ron Judd Jerry Large Seattle Sketcher Jon Talton Danny Westneat Jobs Autos Homes Listings Classifieds Paid Obituaries NWshowcase ShopNW Seattle Times Store Contact FAQs Subscriber Services Print Replica iOS App Android App Business Login Subscribe Amazon Business Wal-Mart skimps on profits to chase Amazon Originally published November 19, 2016 at 8:00 am Updated November 18, 2016 at 5:47 pm Wal-Mart is chasing Amazon; Blue Nile’s smaller format coming to Bellevue Square this coming week; Paul Allen’s painting sold; Share story By Seattle Times staff Seattle Times business staff Wal-Mart seems to be taking a page from archrival Amazon.com’s playbook: earn less in order to grow more. Net income at the Arkansas-based king of retailers fell 8.2 percent to $3 billion for its latest quarter, compared with the same period last year. A big reason: It rolled out pay increases across its legions of workers to better the experience at its cavernous stores. Wal-Mart is also investing big in technology as it digests its acquisition of Jet.com, an e-commerce player that sought to challenge Amazon. Jet’s founder, Marc Lore, is now part of Wal-Mart’s leadership team. At the same time, revenues, which have been stagnating for many large brick-and-mortar retailers, rose 0.7 percent, a result greatly helped by rising e-commerce sales. (Factoring out foreign-exchange gyrations resulting from a stronger U.S. dollar, revenue rose 2.5 percent.) Most Read Stories Flesh-eating bacteria traced to tilapia bought from Bellevue market 35 reasons the Seahawks' Jon Ryan is the punter we all want to be Bus riders step in as driver has fatal heart attack on viaduct Earl Thomas, Rob Gronkowski have cool Twitter exchange about hard hit in Sunday's game Trump supporter in state Senate says some protests are ‘economic terrorism,’ should be feloniesUnlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. “We take the view that profitability decline is a necessary evil over the short term if it allows Wal-Mart to retain its retail prominence,” wrote Neal Saunders, CEO of research firm Conlumino, in a report that compared it to “Amazon’s acceptance of lower profits in order to drive growth.” Due to these investments in people and tech, Saunders concludes that Wal-Mart “is now on a much more positive trajectory in terms of both its e-commerce strategy and results.” But the Arkansas company doesn’t seem to enthrall Wall Street as much as Amazon has, thanks to the latter’s epic double-digit growth in revenue. On Thursday, Wal-Mart shares closed down 3.1 percent at $69.19. The company is valued at about $217 billion, or about 58 percent of Amazon’s worth. Maybe, as Saunders puts it, “Wal-Mart will need to show that its investments are delivering returns, especially on the e-commerce front.” — Ángel González: agonzalez@seattletimes.com Blue Nile ‘webroom’ opening in Bellevue Online jeweler Blue Nile is expanding its brick-and-mortar footprint as the company prepares to open one of its small-format showrooms in Bellevue Square next week. The Seattle-based company hasn’t set an exact date but says it will open sometime Thanksgiving week on the first floor in the south wing of Bellevue Square. It’s the company’s fifth so-called “webroom”; the company opened the first in June 2015 at Roosevelt Field mall in Garden City, N.Y. The webrooms are much smaller than traditional mall jewelry stores. And while customers can see and try on some of the company’s products in the stores, all purchases will be done online through tablets in the stores. Its salespeople are noncommissioned. The company expects to add five more stores next year and plans to eventually have dozens. Blue Nile first tested display cases of its jewelry at a few Nord­strom stores a couple of years ago; those displays have since closed. The bright-and-white webrooms include a panoramic TV wall where videos and live feeds of postings from the company’s social-media fans are featured. CEO Harvey Kanter said the rent and staff costs of the showroom are less than running advertising through Google to draw in customers. Blue Nile is among the formerly online-only pure plays, including Amazon and Warby Parker, that are expanding their brick-and-mortar presence. “Most people want to touch, feel and look before they make a purchase. They do like the tactile experience,” said Brendan Witcher, an analyst at Forrester Research. More and more shoppers are researching online first, then buying at a store. This year, about $376 billion of the $3.4 trillion in overall retail sales will be done online. — Janet I. Tu: jtu@seattletimes.com Allen’s painting sold for $26 million Billionaire Paul Allen’s painting of a war jet by Gerhard Richter fetched $25.6 million at Phillips on Wednesday in New York. Bloomberg News reports. The 1963 canvas, “Dusenjager,” was estimated at $25 million to $35 million, the highest target of 18 works by the 84-year-old German artist on the auction block this past week. Phillips found an irrevocable bidder who agreed in advance to pay an undisclosed minimum price, ensuring the piece sold. Allen, a co-founder with Bill Gates of Microsoft, acquired the painting for $11.2 million in 2007, setting an auction record for the artist at the time. — Bloomberg News Seattle Times staff Email Newsletter Sign-up Custom-curated news highlights, delivered weekday mornings. [Poll] BuzzWorthy 2016-11-19 WWII Shipwrecks Vanish From Pacific Ocean: Sunken Dutch, British Warships, And A U.S. Submarine Mysteriously Disappear From Bottom Of Java Sea SUBSCRIBE Full RSS Feed Latest News Feed Entertainment News Feed Tech Feed World News Gaming Feed Sports Feed Funny & Strange Feed Health Feed Lifestyle Feed BuzzWorthy Feed Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Delivered To Your INBOX Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Email Address Or follow us online Facebook Twitter Google-plus Rss Why You Should Stay Home On Black Friday – Those Deals Aren’t Deals And Mob Mentality Is No Joke Opinion 29 0 0 November 19, 2016 Why You Should Stay Home On Black Friday – Those Deals Aren’t Deals And Mob Mentality Is No Joke Amy Schaeffer The following article is entirely the opinion of Amy Schaeffer and does not reflect the views of the Inquisitr. Ah, Black Friday. Many people seem to anticipate it far more than Thanksgiving, and each year retail stores seem to start their sales earlier – for many stores, people can start shopping on Thanksgiving Day. Push the turkey aside, it’s time to hit Walmart! Or is it? “Black Friday” has come to be a double-edged sword in many peoples’ minds – for those who work retail, it is likely met with dread, as it cuts into their Thanksgiving time with family and subjects them to hordes of people, some of which have become unruly and occasionally violent. In fact, store employees and shoppers have been killed on Black Friday, usually from being trampled to death, such as the Walmart worker who died when eager and frenzied shoppers knocked doors down and stampeded a Walmart on an early Black Friday morning. The most recent death is that of a Walmart employee in Long Island, New York, according to the New York Daily News. People may shake their heads at how people could so carelessly regard a human life because of a “good deal” on appliances or electronics, but the psychology behind the instances of stampedes on Black Friday is nothing new in the realm of human behavior, experts agree. Kenneth Manning, a professor of marketing at Colorado State University, in an interview with LiveScience, says there is a reason that people seem to lose their collective minds in hopes of a “good deal.” “When they can look in the environment and find different cues that make them think they’re getting a good deal, the decision-making can be somewhat emotional.” In fact, studies have found that deal-finding frenzies, real or perceived, cause a release of oxytocin, a chemical of bonding that causes loving and positive feelings – so it’s no wonder what when combined with the cultural norm that has become “Black Friday,” people are not collectively being their most rational selves. Even with that phenomenon, violence is fairly rare, though incivility in stores may not be. Even if you are the type that can overlook bad behavior, it’s time to “talk turkey:” your “Black Friday” savings are not that great, and they may even be a scam or more expensive than you’d normally pay, according to how retail stores promote and sell items. [Image by Ken Cavanaugh/Getty Images] According to Business Insider, there are solid economic reasons about why people should avoid “Black Friday” shopping. Those flyers that promise “door-buster” savings probably are just that – they may cause people to bust down a door (which, as referenced earlier in this article, has killed people) – but the majority off the time, they are not the lowest prices of the season, which typically peaks about nine days before Christmas. And, to make it even more unbearable that you’re waking up at four a.m. (or leaving family behind at Thanksgiving dinner), Kyle James, founder of Rather-be-shopping.com, says that most of the “deals” are on off-brand goods. The relevance of this fact is dependent on your particular needs, James says. “The problem is the brands you’ll find on sale are typically unrecognizable. If you’re a college student and looking for a disposable TV from Best Buy for your dorm room you’ll want to head out Black Friday morning. If you’re looking for a quality TV that will hold up for the long run, you’ll want to look for deals right after Christmas through Super Bowl Sunday.” [Image by Kena Betancur/Getty Images] James also said that the best deals are occurring the three days before Thanksgiving, not after. “The early bird does indeed get the worm. By ‘early bird,’ I’m not talking about being the first one through the doors on Thanksgiving or Black Friday. I’m talking about shopping on the Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday before Black Friday and scoring a deal.” However, if you’re a person who enjoys that side of an oxytocin rush along with your turkey entrée, go bravely forward with the crowd. Keep in mind, though, according to Black Friday Death Count, seven people have died and 98 were injured in Black Friday-related accidents from 2006 to 2014. The statistics on 2015 have yet to be added. Causes of injury included stampedes, fights, and falling asleep while driving home from shopping due to lack of sleep and waiting in lines all night. How you choose to spend the Thanksgiving holiday is, of course, up to you. I’ll be spending it in my house with a hot cup of coffee. [Featured Image by Ian McKinnel/Getty Images] Now Watch This: Val Chmerkovskiy Sued For $6 Million After Posting Insulting Meme Now Read This: Federal Judge John Primomo Tells New U.S. Citizens If They Don’t Like Trump, They Should ‘Go To Another Country’ Share 29 Tweet 0 Share 0 Share 0 Pin It 0 Author Amy Schaeffer Tags: Black Friday deaths, Black Friday false deals, Black Friday Injuries, black friday shopping Comments LATEST HEADLINES Chris Brown To Perform At The AMAs? Walmart Black Friday 2016   The Walmart Black Friday Sale starts 3 hours earlier than last year. The sale begins at 9pm PST on Wednesday. Walmart confirmed the launch time of the Walmart Black Friday 2016 sale online. The Black Friday deals will be released at 9pm PST on Wednesday, November 23. This is midnight for east coast shoppers. Based our observations of the Walmart Black Friday sale, deal hunters can expect to find leaked Black Friday deals available before 9pm PST. Don't Miss: Hatchimals Deals on Amazon.com The Walmart Black Friday deals are this year available earlier than ever. Last year Walmart announced to start offering Black Friday deals online 3 hours later at 12:01am PT. Black Friday shoppers had to wait for grueling 60 minutes to start purchasing Black Friday deals. Walmart delayed the launch due to severe server issues. Let's see if the Walmart servers keep up working this year. It's recommended to shop the Walmart's Black Friday sale as early as possible. This is one of the most popular Black Friday sales and Walmart's servers have been rendered unresponsive by the load. The "early bird" shopper not only has the advantage of a working shopping cart, but also all deals are in stock. We predict that Walmart will have sold out of the $99 New Nintendo 3DS, and other hot items by 5am ET, Thanksgiving Day. A wide range of advertised Black Friday deals will be on sale in the online Black Friday event at walmart.com. Customers can take advantage of the early availability of Walmart's best Black Friday deals from home or from a Walmart store waiting for the 6pm in-store doorbuster event. The Walmart Black Friday 2016 Ad features 4K Ultra HDTVs deals, such as a Phillips 55-inch Smart 4KTV for $298 and a Samsung 50-inch Smart 4K TV for $398. Other television offers consist of a Vizio 60-inch HDTV for $398, a 40-inch HDTV for $125 and 50-inch HDTV for $225 (special buy).  Walmart will have Hatchimals on sale for $48.88 on Black Friday. Disney Princess Cinderella Royal Dreams Dollhouse with Furniture for $88 ($61 savings), Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles RC Mikey for $39 (a Walmart exclusive at a $10 savings) and Razor Hovertrax 2.0 Hoverboard for $273 ($125 savings).  The Samsung Chromebook 3 is advertised for $119 (special buy), HP 15.6-inch Touch Laptop for $249 (special buy) and iPad Mini 2 32GB for $199 ($70 savings). Drones including the DJI Drone Phantom Standard 3 will be on sale for $369 ($130 savings), Promark 3D Virtual Reality HD Drone for $99 (a Walmart exclusive at a $49 savings) and Sharper Image Video Drone for $30 (special buy).  Customers can find more than 750 DVDs and Blu-ray Movies starting at $1.96 in the Walmart Black Friday 2016 sale. Walmart offers deals on fitness wearables including the Fitbit Charge 2 for $129 ($20 savings), Fitbit Alta for $99 ($30 savings) and Fitbit Flex 2 for $69 ($30 savings). Walmart has stocked its warehouse with more than 1.5 million televisions, nearly two million tablets and computers and three million video games for the Walmart Black Friday 2016 sale. The Walmart Black Friday 2016 Ad features these Top 10 Black Friday 2016 deals. Shopping Walmart for Black Friday doorbuster deals is harder than last year. The 1-Hour guarantee deals are no more. The Walmart Pre-Black Friday deals are on sale now at walmart.com. The 32" Samsung UN32J450 720p Smart TV is on sale for $157.99 along with several other Samsung TVs with steep discounts. The best-selling deal in the Walmart Pre-Black Friday sale is the $577.99 60-inch Samsung UN60J6200 Smart TV. Walmart also continues to offer Xbox One S Bundles.  Buyers of the Microsoft Xbox One S 500GB Holiday bundles receive a free bonus game, a 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray movie and a wired Controller for the regular $299 price. Walmart owned membership warehouse Sam's Club is hosting today a Black Friday sale on Samsung TVs and other items from the South Korean consumer giant. The Sam's Club Pre-Black Friday 2016 deals will go on sale on Sunday. This Black Friday 2016 Online Sale schedule gives a quick overview over the launch times of the online Black Friday sales. Most online Black Friday 2016 sales will preempt the Black Friday sales event in stores. The Black Friday 2016 Store Hour Schedule provides an overview of when stores open for Black Friday. Black Friday 2016 deals are on sale now. The Black Friday Deals Tracker helps deal hunters to quickly find the Black Friday 2016 deals on sale right now online. New this year is the Amazon Black Friday 2016 Deals Tracker. The Amazon Black Friday 2016 sale is the biggest sale to find Black Friday deals. The Top 100 Black Friday 2016 Deals show all deals that everybody is talking about this year. The list features the Black Friday deals that Black Friday deal hunters can be proud of to have scored when Black Friday is over. Timing is everything in scoring the best Black Friday 2016. Check the Black Friday 2016 Deals Tracker on a regular basis. To not miss a Black Friday deal, sign up our Twitter feed, where we notify followers about every hot Black Friday deal. You can find over 70 Black Friday 2016 Ads including the most popular ads from Amazon, Walmart, Target and Best Buy. We have compiled everything you need to know about Black Friday 2016 in our Black Friday 2016 guide. When is Black Friday? Black Friday is now, but the actual Black Friday 2016 is on November 25. Premium Advice Help Fool Answers Contact Us Login MENU Latest Stock Picks News Investing News Fool Podcasts Guides How to Invest Retirement Personal Finance Motley Fool Answers Options Trading Find a Broker Compare IRA Accounts ETF - Exchange Traded Funds Community Discussion Boards CAPS More About Help My Fool My Fool My Profile My Watchlist My Scorecard My Boards My CAPS My Reports My Subscriptions My Settings Premium Advice My Services None Other Services None Help Fool Answers Contact Us Login Search Search: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Just Made 2 Big Stock Moves Berkshire made a surprising purchase, and a not-so-surprising stock sale during the third quarter of 2016. Matthew Frankel (TMFMathGuy) Nov 19, 2016 at 8:23AM Image source: The Motley Fool. In a recently released SEC filing, it was revealed that Warren Buffett-led Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRK-A) (NYSE:BRK-B) had opened new stakes in all four major U.S. airlines, which came as a big surprise to many of the company's shareholders, myself included. In addition, Buffett and company got rid of more than two-thirds of a stake it has held for some time. Here are the details of these two moves and why the company might have made them. A surprising bet on airlines Berkshire's SEC filings revealed stakes in American Airlines (NASDAQ:AAL), Delta Air Lines (NYSE:DAL), and United Continental Holdings (NYSE:UAL). Separately, Buffett revealed that Berkshire had also purchased shares of Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV) after the third quarter ended. This was a surprise to Berkshire shareholders, particularly because Buffett has been negative on airlines throughout much of his investing career, ever since a 1989 investment in US Airways preferred stock went sour. For the next several years, he referred to the investment as a mistake, and in 2007 he said, "The worst sort of business is one that grows rapidly, requires significant capital to engender the growth, then earns little or no money. Think airlines." Per his usual policy, Buffett didn't say why he made the airline investments, but there are a few things Berkshire followers should know. For starters, as my colleague Adam Levine-Weinberg pointed out in a separate article, airline stocks plunged in late June in the wake of the Brexit vote, just before the start of the third quarter. In fact, a couple of the airlines have rallied by more than 50% since then. So, it's possible that Buffett or his stock pickers simply saw deeply undervalued stocks and wanted to take advantage. DAL data by YCharts. In addition, the airline business has changed significantly since Buffett last dipped his toes in the water. Airlines have done a good job of keeping expenses in check in recent years, and have produced strong margins. All are generating strong cash flow, and have been aggressive about returning capital to shareholders. A not-so-surprising sale In a less-surprising move, Berkshire reported that it got rid of about 70% of its stake in Wal-Mart Stores (NYSE:WMT), a large amount of stock that is valued at about $2.1 billion as I write this. I say that this isn't much of a surprise for a couple of reasons. First, Berkshire has been disposing of its Wal-Mart stake in recent quarters. The previous sales have been much smaller, but it has become clear that Berkshire has a somewhat bearish view of Wal-Mart right now. While we don't know for sure exactly why Berkshire is getting rid of Wal-Mart, I can say with confidence that it is becoming less of a "Buffett stock." Specifically, it has been gradually losing the competitive advantage it enjoyed in the pre-internet economy. In its prime, Wal-Mart was able to undercut virtually every other retailer, thanks to its scale, no-frills store design, and efficient distribution network. These days, this simply isn't the case. Internet retailers, particularly Amazon.com, can operate just as efficiently as Wal-Mart, and as a result, Wal-Mart's market share has begun to erode. To be perfectly clear, Wal-Mart will be just fine as a business, but an eroding market share and competitive advantage are the exact opposite of what Warren Buffett likes to see in his stock investments. Should you follow Buffett? Not necessarily. I wouldn't go so far as to call the airlines a bad investment right now, but it's safe to say that they're significantly more expensive than the price Buffett paid for them. And Wal-Mart still has a bright future ahead of it, in my opinion, so I'd be reluctant to sell if I were already a shareholder. It can be a great idea to follow the moves of billionaire investors -- not necessarily to make the same moves, but for the investing lessons that can be learned. For example, in Wal-Mart's case, the lesson is "when the reasons you originally bought a stock no longer apply, it's time to reevaluate your investment." There are valuable lessons you can learn from all of Buffett's investment activity, so it's important to read between the lines when he (or another billionaire) buys or sells a stock. Matthew Frankel owns shares of Berkshire Hathaway (B shares). The Motley Fool owns shares of and recommends Berkshire Hathaway (B shares). Try any of our Foolish newsletter services free for 30 days. We Fools may not all hold the same opinions, but we all believe that considering a diverse range of insights makes us better investors. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy. Author Matthew Frankel (TMFMathGuy) Matt brought his love of teaching and investing to the Fool in 2012 in order to help people invest better. Matt specializes in writing about the best opportunities in bank stocks, REITs, and personal finance, but loves any investment at the right price. Follow me on Twitter to keep up with all of the best financial coverage! Close Skip to main content sign in Saved for later Comment activity Edit profile Email preferences Change password Sign out become a supporter subscribe search jobs more from the guardian: jobs change edition: switch to the UK edition switch to the AU edition switch to the INT edition US edition switch to the UK edition switch to the Australia edition switch to the International The Guardian home home election 2016 US world opinion sports soccer tech arts lifestyle fashion business travel environment browse all sections close Guardian sustainable business Values-led business Those luxury Egyptian cotton sheets you own may not be luxurious – or Egyptian Target and Walmart are pulling bedding off their shelves after a falsely labeled Egyptian cotton products controversy involving manufacturer Welspun India Agricultural employees harvest cotton in a field in Benha, Egypt. Welspun India, a giant home textile manufacturer, is in trouble for falsely advertising bedding products as containing Egyptian cotton. Photograph: Bloomberg/Getty Images Supported by About this content Alison Moodie Saturday 19 November 2016 09.00 EST Last modified on Saturday 19 November 2016 09.02 EST Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email View more sharing options Share on LinkedIn Share on Pinterest Share on Google+ Share on WhatsApp Share on Messenger Close Egyptian cotton, which can be spun into fine, long fiber to make sheets with a high thread count, is synonymous with luxury bedding. But in the last four months, it’s been at the center of a controversy that has caused many Americans to wonder whether the Egyptian cotton sheets they rely on for a good night’s sleep actually contain any cotton from Egypt. Why aren't more big brands designing clothes for people with disabilities? Read more The controversy involves Welspun India, a giant home textile manufacturer. Target, Walmart and a handful of other big US retailers have pulled hundreds of thousands of bedding sheets off shelves after discovering that Welspun had sold them falsely labeled Egyptian cotton products. Welspun has seen its stock price tumble since Target led the defection in August when an investigation by the retailer found the 750,000 sheets and pillow cases that Welspun labeled as 100% Egyptian cotton were actually fake. Bed, Bath & Beyond, also one of Welspun’s top customers, is the latest to stop selling the manufacturer’s 100% Egyptian cotton sheets, Bloomberg reported. Welspun, which sells its goods in more than 50 countries and generated $871.4m in annual revenue, is now facing consumer lawsuits over the fake sheets. Most recently, a suit was filed against Walmart, alleging that the store knew about the problem for years but didn’t pull the sheets until two months ago. The trouble Welspun is in demonstrates both the difficulties of monitoring a supply chain that stretches around the world and the power of a label to entice consumers to pay more for products they perceive to be superior. The Egyptian cotton label doesn’t present a verified claim of quality – all it signifies is that the cotton is grown in Egypt. The connection to luxury comes from the recognition that the cotton makes for strong, soft and tightly woven fabric. There are around 10 varieties of cotton farmed in Egypt, according to the US Department of Agriculture. The trouble of verifying a product’s origin and quality pops up in many products, not just bedding. It’s fairly common in the food business: Whole Foods and Safeway, for example, are among the major supermarkets that have gotten in trouble for selling extra virgin oil from Italy that didn’t meet either claim. Welspun is now facing a credibility check from one of the industry groups it belongs to: the Better Cotton Initiative (BCI), which aims to promote the production of sustainable cotton. Part of the BCI’s role is to set standards to ensure the cotton its members use is in fact sustainably grown and harvested. Matthew Kempen, a spokesperson for the initiative, noted that the phrase “Egyptian cotton” is more of an indicator of quality and sustainability, and that BCI doesn’t verify the origins of cotton. “As a matter of precaution we shall be contacting Welspun about the incident to request that they share their corrective actions with us, and we shall remind them that members contribute to credibility of BCI as a framework,” said Kempen. Dishonesty hurts a brand’s reputation as well as sales, said Tulin Erdem, a business and marketing professor who specializes in brand reputation management at New York University’s Stern School of Business. Welspun’s shares dropped by nearly 43% in the week following the announcement from Target, which was the manufacturer’s second largest customer and accounted for $90m, or 10% of the company’s business, in the fiscal year that ended in March. Retailers play a part in ensuring consumers get what they’re paying for. Although it can be difficult to track every manufacturer’s claim, retailers have a responsibility to take action promptly when they suspect dishonesty, said Erdem. Walmart’s actions – and whether it reacted quickly enough to protect its customers –are also under scrutiny. The lawsuit against Walmart claims that the company first became suspicious of Welspun’s Egyptian cotton label back in 2008, but only pulled the product off its shelves in September, after Target announced it was doing the same. Walmart declined to comment. Target said it was phasing out all products manufactured by Welspun under the “Fieldcrest” label after an investigation revealed sheets produced by the company between August 2014 and July 2016 used non-Egyptian cotton. This startup is using jellyfish to make eco-friendly tampons, diapers and pads Read more “Retailers with a good reputation should be vigilant about whether the claimed quality is indeed the delivered quality,” Erdem said. “The decisions about what brands to carry need to be made carefully, and that is part of quality management for a manufacturer.” Welspun did not respond to the Guardian’s request for comment. The company said in a statement in September to shareholders that it had hired an accounting firm to investigate its cotton suppliers. “We take the current traceability concerns around some of our product lines very seriously,” the company said. Welspun said the products under investigation represented 6% of the company’s annual business, and its deal with Walmart accounted for 1.5% of annual sales. The dwindling supply of Egyptian cotton could be a factor that leads cotton suppliers to cheat. Egyptian cotton production has been on a steady decline over the past decade as the global price for cotton has dropped and the Egyptian government has removed subsidies to help farmers. According to the US Department of Agriculture, Egypt is expected to produce 395,000 bales of cotton in 2017, down from nearly 940,000 bales in 2005. While verifying claims on labels can be challenging, technology is making it easier for retailers to at least check the reputation of certain brands, said Erdem. A laboratory outside New York City offers DNA testing to verify whether textiles are made of premium cotton. If they are, a tiny barcode is sprayed on the cotton before it is turned into yarn, allowing it to be tracked throughout the production process. “Certain claims are almost not verifiable, such as whether a certain cream delays the onset of wrinkles in the long run,” said Erdem. “But some others are easier to verify, such as the origin of the main raw material.” More features Topics Farming Retail industry Walmart Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email Share on LinkedIn Share on Pinterest Share on Google+ Share on WhatsApp Share on Messenger Close Reuse this content View all comments > Order by newest oldest recommendations Show 25 25 50 100 All Threads collapsed expanded unthreaded Loading comments… Trouble loading? Christmas and Thanksgiving Specials would be hard to negate. Walmart is about almost everything but the big retailers leaked Black Friday ads and flyers are mostly about tech items. Long-awaited Walmart Black Friday 2016 ad deals have finally arrived.  This is the 2nd year when Walmart is offering majority of its Black Friday deals online, because more and more people are segregating their budgets between online and in-store. Offering Wristbands for certain popular items, has become a tradition for Walmart that guarantees every shopper who receives a wristband will get the product for sure even if goes out of stock. To help you locate the in-demand items that sell out fast such as TVs and toys, Walmart has launched interactive store maps, which highlights the popular product location. Millions of shoppers last year accessed these store maps. Walmart Black Friday 2016 ad sales online begin at 12.01 on Thanksgiving Day and in-store doorbuster deals begin at 6PM the same day! Login Page Archives Les Actualités Breaking News Relocation winds swirl around Carolina Hurricanes Excitement Not Lost on Young Maple Leafs Wal-Mart Tackles Food Safety with Blockchain Test Tesla Acquires Solar Panel Company For $2 Billion ‘The Valuations are Really stupid’: Marijuana Stocks Spike Trip Circuit Breakers, Temporarily Halted lecanadian Canada's socially conscious lifestyle magazine Home business entertainment fashion foodie headline news health Letters · Editorials lifestyle sports UFO · Exopolitics Wal-Mart Tackles Food Safety with Blockchain Test If you shop at Wal-Mart, you might be buying packaged produce unlike any ever sold in a U.S. store. The sliced apples or cut broccoli — the merchant won’t say exactly what’s involved — are being used to test blockchain, a new database technology. If successful, the trial could change how Wal-Mart Stores, which serves some 260 million customers a week, monitors food and takes action when something goes wrong. That could spur big leaps in food safety, cut costs and save lives. Like most merchants, the world’s largest retailer struggles to identify and remove food that’s been recalled. When a customer becomes ill, it can take days to identify the product, shipment and vendor. With the blockchain, Wal-Mart will be able to obtain crucial data from a single receipt, including suppliers, details on how and where food was grown and who inspected it. The database extends information from the pallet to the individual package. “It gives them an ability to have an accounting from origin to completion,” said Marshal Cohen, an analyst at researcher NPD Group Inc. “If there’s an issue with an outbreak of E. coli, this gives them an ability to immediately find where it came from. That’s the difference between days and minutes.” It’s also the difference between pulling a few tainted packages and yanking all the spinach from hundreds of stores, according to Frank Yiannas, vice president of food safety at Bentonville, Arkansas-based Wal-Mart. “With blockchain, you can do strategic removals, and let consumers and companies have confidence,” Yiannas said. “We believe that enhanced traceability is good for other aspects of the food systems. We hope you could capture other important attributes that would inform decisions around food flows, and even get more efficient at it.” More than 1,000 foodborne outbreaks investigated by state and local health departments are reported each year, according to the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention. The CDC estimates roughly 48 million people are afflicted annually, with 128,000 hospitalized and 3,000 dying. Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. has suffered a year of falling sales as a result of several outbreaks. In October, Wal-Mart started tracking two products using blockchain: a packaged produce item in the U.S., and pork in China. While only two items were included, the test involved thousands of packages shipped to multiple stores. The blockchain is a distributed ledger where companies doing business with one another, such as growers, distributors and retailers, can record transactions securely. The database’s strength lies in its trustworthiness: the difficulty of reversing or changing what’s been recorded. The blockchain database can also hold much more data than what retailers get today, providing tools for more detailed analysis. That could help Wal-Mart deliver food to stores faster, reducing spoilage and waste. Cutting costs is critical for all retailers. Last year, retail sales rose only 2.1 per cent, the smallest gain since 2009, according to Retail Industry Leaders Association. Traditional offline retailers continue to be pressured by Amazon.com Inc. and its efficient supply chain. If the tests are successful, Wal-Mart will expand them to multiple food items in both countries, Yiannis said. “So far things are flowing smoothly and as expected,” he said. Wal-Mart has been at the forefront of adopting new technologies before. It began installing new chip-card readers at U.S. checkout counters 10 years before the deadline mandated by credit-card networks like Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. This summer, it took Walmart Pay nationwide, becoming one of the first large retailers to launch its own mobile-payment service. It’s also expanding its online grocery delivery service. The blockchain, a technology that only came onto the scene in 2009, is already being widely tested by companies in the financial, healthcare and natural-resource industries. Companies like International Business Machines Corp., the Nasdaq and BHP Billiton Ltd. have deployed or are planning to deploy it to run their businesses more efficiently. Wal-Mart is using blockchain technology co-developed by IBM. In October, the company opened the Walmart Food Safety Collaboration Center in Beijing. It also announced, with IBM and Tsinghua University, a collaboration using the blockchain to improve the way food is tracked, transported and sold to Chinese consumers. If Wal-Mart adopts the blockchain to track food worldwide, it could become of the largest deployments of the technology to date. “They are setting the new standards in terms of how technology can be implemented to solve a problem that’s been with us for ages,” said Paul Chang, global supply chain subject matter expert at IBM. Black Friday Tech Apple Science Cars Celebrity Movies Holiday Gifts Cyber Monday     NES Classic In Stock At Best Buy This Weekend: Rumor Posted: Nov 19 2016, 4:59am CST | by Luigi Lugmayr, Updated: Nov 19 2016, 6:22am CST, in News | Black Friday   This story may contain affiliate links.   The Nintendo NES Classic is sold out online. The hard to find NES is rumored to be in stores this weekend. The Nintendo NES Classic is sold out online. The last chance to buy a NES Classic for the regular price of $59.99 was on Friday in the 5th flash sale of the NES Classic online at walmart.com. This promotion has now ended and Walmart has not announced a new NES sale.  Don't Miss: Top 100 Black Friday 2016 Deals Walmart was the only online store besides GameStop that offered the new mini Nintendo Entertainment System all week. GameStop offered a bundle deal the last time on Tuesday. The NES Classic launched on November 11. Nintendo had now over a week to resupply stores and the might have done just that. We already said in our latest report about the Hatchimals that retailers are shifting their limited inventories away from online shops for the Thanksgiving week. Hatchimals are more likely to be in stock at stores over the course of next week. We believe the same is true for the rare NES Classic. A rumor on a video game discussion forum supports that theory. A long time forum member at CheapAssGamer posted that a retail employee told him that Best Buy is getting a stock this weekend on Saturday and Sunday. He cautioned that he can't confirm the rumor. As the NES Classic is extremely hard to find any lead is worthwhile exploring. Visit your local Best Buy store ahead of the store opening hour to not miss out of possible stock of NES. Ask store employees about the availability of the NES.  It is also worthwhile the effort to visit the other stores that are known to carry the NES Classic. The list of stores include GameStop, Target, ToysRUs and Walmart. We'd love to hear from you in case you have information about the NES stock situation at your local store. We will send out our reporter to the malls starting Monday. The NES Classic Edition starts at $229.99 from resellers at the Amazon Market Place. On eBay the Nintendo NES Classic Edition is listed for $199 in non-auction offers.   The new Nintendo Entertainment System is a perfect product for the Holidays. It works great as gift for adults as well as kids. Families can enjoy playing the simple video games from the 80s together. There are 3rd party controllers and accessories that make the NES more fun to use. Nintendo knows it messed up, underestimating the demand for the NES Classic Edition. Nintendo has issued a statement on Twitter on November 11 acknowledging the shortage of the NES Classic Edition. "The Nintendo Entertainment System: NES Classic Edition system is a hot item, and we are working hard to keep up with consumer demand. There will be a steady flow of additional systems through the holiday shopping season and into the new year. Please contact your local retailers to check availability." The shrunk NES console, retailing for $59.99 list price, features the classic Nintendo NES controller many geeks have grown up with. The retro console comes pre-installed with 30 classic NES games including Super Mario Bros., Pac-Man, Metroid, Donkey Kong, The Legend of Zelda and Kirby's Adventures. The NES Classic Edition system is a miniaturized version of the groundbreaking NES, originally released in 1985. Find more Holiday Gifts, alternatives to these hard to get toys, in the I4U News Holiday Gift Guide. The big Amazon Black Friday 2016 sale has launched. Find the current Amazon deals in our Amazon Black Friday 2016 Deals Tracker. Restaurants Real Estate Home Business Wal-Mart tackles food safety print Share | e-mail Facebook Tweet StumbleUpon Google Wal-Mart tackles food safety Bloomberg News Published Nov 19, 2016 at 12:02AM If you shop at Wal-Mart, you might be buying packaged produce unlike any ever sold in a U.S. store. The sliced apples or cut broccoli — the merchant won’t say exactly what’s involved — are being used to test blockchain, a new database technology. If successful, the trial could change how Wal-Mart Stores, which serves some 260 million customers a week, monitors food and takes action when something goes wrong. That could spur big leaps in food safety, cut costs and save lives. Like most merchants, the world’s largest retailer struggles to identify and remove food that’s been recalled. When a customer becomes ill, it can take days to identify the product, shipment and vendor. With the blockchain, Wal-Mart will be able to obtain crucial data from a single receipt, including suppliers, details on how and where food was grown and who inspected it. The database extends information from the pallet to the individual package. “It gives them an ability to have an accounting from origin to completion,” said Marshal Cohen, an analyst at researcher NPD Group Inc. “If there’s an issue with an outbreak of E. coli, this gives them an ability to immediately find where it came from. That’s the difference between days and minutes.” It’s also the difference between pulling a few tainted packages and yanking all the spinach from hundreds of stores, according to Frank Yiannas, vice president of food safety at Bentonville, Arkansas-based Wal-Mart. “With blockchain, you can do strategic removals, and let consumers and companies have confidence,” Yiannas said. “We believe that enhanced traceability is good for other aspects of the food systems. We hope you could capture other important attributes that would inform decisions around food flows, and even get more efficient at it.” More than 1,000 foodborne outbreaks investigated by state and local health departments are reported each year, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The CDC estimates roughly 48 million people are afflicted annually, with 128,000 hospitalized and 3,000 dying. Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. has suffered a year of falling sales as a result of several outbreaks. In October, Wal-Mart started tracking two products using blockchain: a packaged produce item in the U.S., and pork in China. While only two items were included, the test involved thousands of packages shipped to multiple stores. The blockchain is a distributed ledger where companies doing business with one another, such as growers, distributors and retailers, can record transactions securely. The database’s strength lies in its trustworthiness: the difficulty of reversing or changing what’s been recorded. The blockchain database can also hold much more data than what retailers get today, providing tools for more detailed analysis. That could help Wal-Mart deliver food to stores faster, reducing spoilage and waste. Cutting costs is critical for all retailers. Last year, retail sales rose only 2.1 percent, the smallest gain since 2009, according to Retail Industry Leaders Association. Traditional offline retailers continue to be pressured by Amazon.com Inc. and its efficient supply chain. If the tests are successful, Wal-Mart will expand them to multiple food items in both countries, Yiannis said. “So far things are flowing smoothly and as expected,” he said. The blockchain, a technology that only came onto the scene in 2009, is already being widely tested by companies in the financial, health care and natural-resource industries. Companies like International Business Machines Corp., the Nasdaq and BHP Billiton Ltd. have deployed or are planning to deploy it to run their businesses more efficiently. Wal-Mart is using blockchain technology co-developed by IBM. In October, the company opened the Walmart Food Safety Collaboration Center in Beijing. It also announced, with IBM and Tsinghua University, a collaboration using the blockchain to improve the way food is tracked, transported and sold to Chinese consumers. If Wal-Mart adopts the blockchain to track food worldwide, it could become of the largest deployments of the technology to date. “They are setting the new standards in terms of how technology can be implemented to solve a problem that’s been with us for ages,” said Paul Chang, global supply chain subject matter expert at IBM. 15656483 View next article in Business     Get Central Oregon's top headlines delivered to your inbox every morning GO print version Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. comments powered by Disqus This image is copyrighted. Target has released a list of Surprise Doorbusters. The items aren't online yet, according to BFAds.net, but here's sneak peek: •   Apex 19" LED HDTV - $99.99 • Westinghouse 24" 1080p LED HDTV - $149.99 • Element 40" 1080p LCD HDTV - $279.99 • Westinghouse 40" 1080p 120Hz LED HDTV - $349.99 • LG 47" 1080p 120Hz LED HDTV - $599.99 • Westinghouse 32" LED HDTV - $199.99 • Samsung 50" 1080p LED HDTV - $699.00 • Samsung 55" 1080p 120Hz LED HDTV - $999.99 • Samsung Soundbar - $179.99 • RCA CD Changer - $99.99 • Netgear NeoTV - no pricing info yet Walmart, Target released Black Friday store maps Walmart and Target want to make it easier to get around their stores on Thanksgiving and Black Friday. The stores have released their Black Friday maps to show shoppers exactly where the most sought-after items are, BFads.net reported. Walmart's store map is available on their app as well as their site. To view your map, click here and select "My Local Store" and "Weekly Ads" to see an option to click on a store map. Not all store maps are available yet. Target also has a store map you can use to locate doorbusters on Black Friday. You can click here and enter your zip code to find your map. Here are some other Black Friday ads: Sephora - Sephora's Black Friday deals will go live online at 12:10 a.m. Thanksgiving morning. From BestBlackFriday.com Lowe's – Lowe's is closed on Thanksgiving, will open at 6 a.m. on Black Friday Pet Smart  - PetSmart will be closed on Thanksgiving with Black Friday hours from 7 a.m.-9 p.m. Online deals will be available starting at 7 a.m. on Thanksgiving. Couple of special offers from PetSmart: Online purchases made Nov. 25-27 will receive free shipping (excluding doorbusters) Doorbusters will be offered 7 a.m.-noon on Black Friday PetSmart is launching its first ever text messaging program that allows customers to opt-in to receive coupons, content and event notifications. You can do that here or text PetSmart to 84848.  Check out other Black Friday ads here: Academy Sports Ace Hardware Amazon Electronics Guide Babies R Us  Bed Bath and Beyond Belk Best Buy Big Lots  Burlington Stores Cabelas CVS Game Stop Dell Black Friday Dell Small Business Black Friday Dell Small Business Cyber Monday Dick's  Express Five Below Goody's Habor Freight Tools hhGregg JoAnn's Fabrics JC Penney Black Friday Kmart  Kohl's Lowe's  Macy's Macy's Doorbusters Michael's  Office Depot/Office Max  Petco Petsmart Rite Aid Sam's Club Samsung Sears  Sephora Staples  Target T-Mobile Toys R Us  Victoria's Secret Walmart Walgreens Thanksgiving Week Holiday catalogs American Armed Forces Exchange Store Bass Pro Shop Big Lots Costco Dollar General Dollar Tree Hallmark Toybooks Dollar General JC Penney Toy Book Kmart Lego Macy's Target Top toy lists Amazon Kmart Target Toys R Us Walmart Most Read Active Discussions About Us About Alabama Media Group Jobs at Alabama Media Group Advertise with us News In Education Frequently Asked Questions About AL.com Contact Us Online Store Already a Subscriber? Life Buy/Sell Business Close 1 of 5 Buy Now Michael Thomas Debbie Elbl, of St. Charles, reads a mall map as holiday decorations is seen inside the Macy's Department store on November 17, 2016 at West County Mall in Des Peres. Most Macy's stores plan to open Thanksgiving evening, close for a few hours and then reopen at 5 a.m. on Black Friday. (Photo by Michael Thomas) Buy Now Michael Thomas From left, Alex Anderson, 20, of Imperial, and Miranda Maheri, 19, of Arnold, walk Nov. 17, 2016, at West County Mall in Des Peres. St. Louis' largest mall operator, CBL, announced it's closing its malls on Thanksgiving this year. Anderson says he usually enjoys watching the shopping madness on Thanksgiving, while Maheri said she's usually working that day. (Photo by Michael Thomas) Buy Now Michael Thomas Shoppers walk along as holiday decorations are seen on November 17, 2016 at West County Mall in Des Peres. St. Louis' largest mall operator, CBL, announced it's closing its malls on Thanksgiving this year. (Photo by Michael Thomas) Malls, retailers tweak hours as holiday shopping rush nears By Lisa Brown St. Louis Post-Dispatch Lisa Brown 4 hrs ago (…) Buy Now Michael Thomas Debbie Elbl, of St. Charles, reads a mall map as holiday decorations is seen inside the Macy's Department store on November 17, 2016 at West County Mall in Des Peres. Most Macy's stores plan to open Thanksgiving evening, close for a few hours and then reopen at 5 a.m. on Black Friday. (Photo by Michael Thomas) Buy Now Michael Thomas From left, Alex Anderson, 20, of Imperial, and Miranda Maheri, 19, of Arnold, walk Nov. 17, 2016, at West County Mall in Des Peres. St. Louis' largest mall operator, CBL, announced it's closing its malls on Thanksgiving this year. Anderson says he usually enjoys watching the shopping madness on Thanksgiving, while Maheri said she's usually working that day. (Photo by Michael Thomas) Buy Now Michael Thomas Shoppers walk along as holiday decorations are seen on November 17, 2016 at West County Mall in Des Peres. St. Louis' largest mall operator, CBL, announced it's closing its malls on Thanksgiving this year. (Photo by Michael Thomas) Buy Now Michael Thomas Sierra Thompson, 22, of Hillsboro, walks along a mall decorated for the holidays on November 17, 2016 at West County Mall in Des Peres. St. Louis' largest mall operator, CBL, announced it's closing its malls on Thanksgiving this year. Thompson, a cashier at Walmart, which plans to open at 6 p.m. on the holiday, has to work. (Photo by Michael Thomas) Buy Now Michael Thomas Shoppers walk along as holiday decorations are seen on November 17, 2016 at West County Mall in Des Peres. St. Louis' largest mall operator, CBL, announced it's closing its malls on Thanksgiving this year. (Photo by Michael Thomas) Shoppers will still have plenty of options to seek out deals at retailers immediately after their Thanksgiving meal this year, even though the largest mall operator in St. Louis won’t be open on the holiday. Target, Kohl’s and Sears will open their doors at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving, and Walmart’s in-store sales begin at 6 p.m. Most Toys R Us, Best Buy and Macy’s stores will open at 5 p.m., and J.C. Penney is hoping to attract shoppers early with a 3 p.m. opening. “We pay associates double-time on Thanksgiving, and we have more people sign up for it than needed,” said Paul Lemmon, general manager of the J.C. Penney at South County Center. The store plans to offer platters of food for its employees around the clock to make it through the night as it remains open past midnight and into Black Friday. J.C. Penney will be the only store in the mall open in the middle of the night, as another anchor, Macy’s, plans to close at 2 a.m. and reopen on Friday morning at 5. Many retailers have scaled back their overnight hours in recent years, including Best Buy, which will close at 1 a.m. on Friday and reopen at 8 a.m. “In 2013, our stores stayed open all night,” said Best Buy spokeswoman Bianca Jones. “Since then, we made the decision to close for several hours. This allows us to clean, restock and reorganize our stores in time for our Friday opening.” Tennessee-based CBL & Associates Properties is closing its malls across the country for Thanksgiving, including its local malls: West County Center, South County Center, Mid Rivers Mall and St. Clair Square. Those malls will open at 6 a.m. on Friday. Mall leaders say they want to give employees the chance to spend time with family on Thanksgiving after several years of being open on the holiday. Chesterfield Mall also will be closed on Thanksgiving and open Friday at 6 a.m. The mall closures on Thanksgiving won’t interrupt the shopping plans of Betty Myers, 66, of Prairie du Rocher, Ill., who was shopping with her daughter Barbie Curten at the Galleria on Friday. “Thanksgiving is a day for family,” Myers said. Early discounts Shoppers’ email inboxes and mailboxes are flooded this time of year with retailers’ ads proclaiming Black Friday discounts available several days and even weeks before the big shopping day that traditionally kicks off the holiday shopping season. “There are a lot of retailers right now already doing sales, with some as good as the Black Friday sales, and we’re definitely seeing the volume of shoppers has begun to increase,” said CBL local marketing director Sean Phillips. “We didn’t see any incremental sales increases by being open on Thanksgiving. Rather, the traffic and sales volume was just spread out over a two-day period.” To attract customers on Black Friday, CBL malls are offering shoppers the chance to win shopping sprees ranging from $250 to $500. CBL also spent “in the six figures” on new holiday décor at West County Center to replace trees, lights and Santa’s seating area in use since 2002 when the mall reopened following a massive redevelopment. Several other malls will be open on Thanksgiving evening, including the two outlet malls in Chesterfield, St. Louis Galleria and Alton Square Mall. At Walmart, the retailer is offering nearly all of its Black Friday deals available in stores on its website beginning just after midnight on Thanksgiving, said Mari Matthes, store manager of the Kirkwood Walmart. Customers can either have the merchandise shipped or they can pick it up in stores. “This year, we’ve dramatically increased the amount of Black Friday merchandise allocated to Walmart.com, by 50 percent,” said spokeswoman Danit Marquardt. A lot of green Holiday purchases made online in the U.S. are expected to surpass the $100 billion mark for the first time, according to market research firm Forrester Research, based in Cambridge, Mass. It forecast online sales of $112 billion, a 13 percent increase from last year. Online sales generally total about 12 percent of annual retail sales, according to Forrester, but that figure jumps to 16 percent in November and December. Meet the best small businesses to work at in St. Louis Who's hired? Check our People in Business See how St. Louis stocks are faring Company headquarters that have moved from St. Louis “While Black Friday and the days leading up to Christmas are the most important shopping days for brick-and-mortar stores, Cyber Monday (the Monday following Thanksgiving) is the biggest online shopping event,” Forrester’s senior analyst Susan Wu wrote in a recent research report. La Royce Gaines, 44, of St. Louis, was shopping Friday afternoon for a friend’s birthday gift at the St. Louis Galleria, but she said she plans to stay far away from malls on Thanksgiving and Black Friday and shop for holiday gifts online only. “I hate fighting for parking, and the long lines are frustrating,” she said. Holiday sales are expected to rise to $655.8 billion in November and December, a 3.6 percent increase from 2015, according to the National Retail Federation, which bases its forecast on consumer credit, disposable personal income and previous monthly retail sales. The figures don’t include autos, gas or restaurant sales. The unemployment rate fell in October to 4.9 percent and on Tuesday, the Commerce Department reported retail sales rose 0.8 percent in October. “October’s strong sales and September’s upward revisions show that consumer spending improved despite the headwinds from the polarizing election and warmer than normal weather,” retail federation Chief Economist Jack Kleinhenz said in a statement. “Recent solid wage gains and other fundamentals are generating uplift, positioning consumers and retailers for the healthy holiday season (National Retail Federation) is forecasting.” Consumers plan to spend an average of $935.58 this holiday season on presents, food, flowers, decorations and greeting cards, according to the federation’s annual consumer spending survey. One area that’s growing is self-spending, or buying discounted goods for yourself during the Black Friday sales. Consumers plan to spend $139.61 on self-spending during the holidays, the second highest amount in the survey’s 13-year history. The record was in 2012, when consumer self-spending totaled $140.43. Still, some consumers feel cautious about their finances. Forty-seven percent of respondents said their household finances are strained, according to a survey conducted by Chicago-based market research firm IRI. “Consumers are really trying to keep their budgets in check,” said Susan Viamari, IRI vice president of thought leadership. Despite consumer caution, shoppers are willing to buy unplanned splurge items. According to the IRI survey, even 13 percent of those with strained finances said they would buy an additional or unplanned item. Business Briefing from St. Louis Post-Dispatch Make it your business. Get twice-daily updates on what the St. Louis business community is talking about. This field is required. Sign Up! leave this blank Lisa Brown • 314-340-8127 @lisabrownstl on Twitter lbrown@post-dispatch.com Holidays topical 50+ of the season's hottest toys put to the test by St. Louis kids Nov 18, 2016 (…) By Valerie Schremp Hahn, Aisha Sultan, Amy Bertrand and Jody Mitori Holiday shopping hours Stores J.C. Penney: Opens at 3 p.m. on Thanksgiving and stays open until 10 p.m. on Black Friday Toys 'R Us: Open at 5 p.m. Thanksgiving Target, Kohl's, Sears and Dick's Sporting Goods: Open at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving Walmart: In-store sales begin at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving Malls West County Center, South County Center, Mid Rivers Mall and St. Clair Square: Closed on Thanksgiving, open 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. on Black Friday. Plaza Frontenac: Closed on Thanksgiving, open 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. on Black Friday. St. Louis Premium Outlets in Chesterfield: Open at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving until 2 a.m., reopening 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. on Black Friday. Taubman Prestige Outlets in Chesterfield: Open at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving until midnight, reopening 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. on Black Friday. Alton Square Mall: Open from 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving until 10 p.m. on Black Friday. Over 100 die in India train derailment World / Asia Sign In Register Companies Energy Financial Services Healthcare Industrials Innovation Investors Monthly Land & Agriculture Management Mining Property Retail & Consumer Telecoms & Technology Trade & Industry Transport & Tourism Business Economy Life Arts & Entertainment Books Motoring Gadgets & Gear Markets National Education Health Labour Media Science & Environment Opinion Columnists Editorials Letters Politics Sport Cricket Other Sport Rugby Soccer World Africa Americas Asia Europe Middle East BL Premium SIGN IN REGISTER Companies How Wal-Mart is using blockchain to make food safer With the blockchain, Wal-Mart will be able to get crucial data from a single receipt, including suppliers, details on how and where food was grown and who inspected it 18 November 2016 - 13:57 PM Olga Kharif A Wal-Mart store Salinas, California, US. Picture: ISTOCK Portland — If you shop at Wal-Mart, you might be buying packaged produce unlike any ever sold in a US store. The sliced apples or cut broccoli — the merchant will not say what’s involved exactly — are being used to test blockchain, a new database technology. If successful, the trial could change how Wal-Mart Stores, which serves some 260-million customers a week, monitors food and takes action when something goes wrong. That could spur big leaps in food safety, cut costs and save lives. Like most merchants, the world’s largest retailer struggles to identify and remove food that has been recalled. When a customer becomes ill, it can take days to identify the product, shipment and vendor. With the blockchain, Wal-Mart will be able to obtain crucial data from a single receipt, including suppliers, details on how and where food was grown and who inspected it. The database extends information from the pallet to the individual package. "It gives them an ability to have an accounting from origin to completion," said Marshal Cohen, an analyst at researcher NPD Group. "If there’s an issue with an outbreak of E.coli, this gives them an ability to immediately find where it came from. That’s the difference between days and minutes." It is also the difference between pulling a few tainted packages and yanking all the spinach from hundreds of stores, according to Frank Yiannas, vice president of food safety at Bentonville, Arkansas-based Wal-Mart. Insurance giants hope blockchain can help them streamline operations "With blockchain, you can do strategic removals, and let consumers and companies have confidence," Yiannas said. "We believe that enhanced traceability is good for other aspects of the food systems. We hope you could capture other important attributes that would inform decisions around food flows, and even get more efficient at it." More than 1,000 foodborne outbreaks investigated by state and local health departments are reported each year, according to the Centre for Disease Control & Prevention. The CDC estimates roughly 48-million people are afflicted annually, with 128,000 hospitalised and 3,000 dying. Chipotle Mexican Grill has suffered a year of falling sales as a result of several outbreaks. Packaged produce In October, Wal-Mart started tracking two products using blockchain: a packaged produce item in the US, and pork in China. While only two items were included, the test involved thousands of packages shipped to multiple stores. The blockchain is a distributed ledger where companies doing business with each other — such as growers, distributors and retailers — can record transactions securely. The database’s strength lies in its trustworthiness: the difficulty of reversing or changing what has been recorded. The blockchain database can also hold much more data than what retailers get today, providing tools for more detailed analysis. That could help Wal-Mart deliver food to stores faster, reducing spoilage and waste. Cutting costs is critical for all retailers. Last year, retail sales rose only 2.1%, the smallest gain since 2009, according to Retail Industry Leaders’ Association. Traditional offline retailers continue to be pressured by Amazon.com and its efficient supply chain. Wider application? If the tests are successful, Wal-Mart will expand them to multiple food items in both countries, Yiannis said. "So far things are flowing smoothly and as expected," he said. Wal-Mart has been at the forefront of adopting new technologies before. It began installing new chip-card readers at US checkout counters 10 years before the deadline mandated by credit-card networks like Visa and Mastercard. This summer, it took Walmart Pay nationwide, becoming one of the first large retailers to launch its own mobile-payment service. It is also expanding its online grocery delivery service. The blockchain, a technology that only came onto the scene in 2009, is already being widely tested by companies in the financial, healthcare and natural-resource industries. Bold forecasts, but the blockchain numbers do not add up Blockchain industry is either hugely underresourced or hugely overoptimistic. Probably both, write Lionel Laurent and Elaine He Opinion 2 months ago Five tech trends to look out for in 2017 Advances that will revolutionise the way companies do business Lifestyle 1 month ago Watch out for the internet of things Artificial intelligence, and augmented and virtual reality could allow businesses to make better decisions in years to come Companies 1 month ago Companies like International Business Machines, the Nasdaq and BHP Billiton have deployed or are planning to deploy it to run their businesses more efficiently. Wal-Mart is using blockchain technology co-developed by IBM. In October, the company opened the Walmart Food Safety Collaboration Centre in Beijing. It also announced, with IBM and Tsinghua University, a collaboration using the blockchain to improve the way food is tracked, transported and sold to Chinese consumers. If Wal-Mart adopts the blockchain to track food worldwide, it could become of the largest deployments of the technology to date. "They are setting the new standards in terms of how technology can be implemented to solve a problem that’s been with us for ages," said Paul Chang, global supply chain subject matter expert at IBM.
