They would like to see a younger crowd moving in, but can't get the businesses in to attract them. Businesses won't invest until they have the younger crowd established. ItÕs a circle the county has been running in for years.  (Photo: Andrea Melendez/The News-Press) What draft report says North Fort Myers can absorb 400 condominiums 120 hotel rooms 320,000 square feet of office space 50,000 square feet of wholesale space 18,000 square feet of new retail space Consultant's proposed steps Improve access to business from the 41s Aggregate property ownership for development Address zoning and building code restrictions Create non-profit development agency or hire county staff to facilitate Create marketing campaign for NFM as "welcoming destination" North Fort Myers demographics: Population: 271,436  (County: 661,115) Median household income: $43,833  (County: $47,908) Average hourly earnings: $14.84  (County:$19.15) Median age: 44.6 years  (County: 46.3) Source: DCG Corplan, draft North Myers Market Assessment study, U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics 5 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE Read or Share this story: http://newspr.es/2g83ZIP TOP VIDEOS TSA: These things didn't make it on to a SWFL airplane Sept and Oct 1:08 Better than an apple. scitech newspapers Shop @ Loot IOL PropertySections International Fedusa's new head to fight for fair wages for all Recommended National Minimum Wage set at R20 per hour SA to pursue decent standard of living for all Time abroad can crystallise career ideas Certainty, growth key in credit grade business international Bed sheet scandal roils the cotton industry International / 19 November 2016, 09:00am Matthew Campbell, Shannon Pettypiece and Rajhkumar K Shaaw New York - Huddled inside Target’s headquarters in downtown Minneapolis, a team of investigators spent the summer trying to answer what should have been a simple question: What were hundreds of thousands of the retailer’s sheets actually made of? What they discovered has undermined trust in a global luxury product and set off a salvo of class-action lawsuits that have created a king-sized public relations challenge for the Indian textiles industry and the US companies it supplies. Turns out that major American retailers, including Target and Wal-Mart Stores Inc., have been selling premium-priced sheets purportedly made of Egyptian cotton - a byword for luxury in linens - but that may in reality be woven with lower-quality cotton blends. Three suits seeking to be certified as class-actions have been filed against supplier Welspun India - and a separate one last week was directed at Wal-Mart. The complaint, filed in New York by customer Dorothy Monahan, accuses the world’s largest retailer of questioning the fibre content of Welspun’s products as early as 2008, but not halting its sales until after Target did so in August. Wal-Mart said it will “vigorously defend” itself. The other lawsuits, all filed in the US against Welspun, allege the company fraudulently labelled its bed sheets as Egyptian cotton. Welspun declined to comment on the suits. MD Rajesh Mandawewala told analysts during a conference call in August that “the error is on our side so we have to take responsibility for it.” Target, meanwhile, hasn’t been sued. “The marketing has created this image in our heads that high-quality cotton and Egypt are synonymous,” said Louis Rose, a Memphis, Tennessee-based cotton industry consultant. “Consumers should be sceptical of these marketing claims. They’ll be under a lot more scrutiny now.” Exhaustive work The fake Egyptian sheet episode came to light after exhaustive work by Target investigators who analysed sheet fibres under microscopes and tracked their journey through a global supply chain. The probe found that 750 000 of Target’s “Egyptian cotton” sheets, sold for as much as $75 a pop, didn’t contain any Egyptian cotton at all, but an amalgam of lower-quality fibres from cheaper sources. That July discovery touched off a scandal spanning from Minnesota to Mumbai and Cairo that threatens the future of Welspun, part of a $3 billion conglomerate headed by entrepreneur Balkrishan Goenka. It may also hobble Indian textile manufacturers in the race to supply Western consumers with high-quality sheets and towels, creating an opening for competitors from China and elsewhere to grab the business, according to industry analysts. The Welspun-made sheets Target examined were sold under the Fieldcrest brand. While it has interests in steel, energy, and infrastructure, textiles are the bread and butter for Welspun, which says it supplies one in five towels sold in America and posted revenue of about $900 million in the 2016 fiscal year. Tennis stars like Roger Federer mop their brows with Welspun towels at the Wimbledon championships - a fact the company highlights in investor presentations. Target has cut ties and ended all of its $90 million in annual business with the company. Wal-Mart Stores and Bed Bath & Beyond Inc. also stopped selling Welspun sheets that had been labelled 100 percent Egyptian cotton. Those are significant blows coming from some of Welspun’s biggest customers, and have sent its stock down about 40 percent since August. 19 when Target announced its decision. The sheets fiasco reflects a simple reality: There’s a scarcity of Egyptian cotton. It first became a key export product in the early 19th century, when it arrived in France and became sought after for its silky feel. Production has been falling since the 1990s, however, and last year Egypt’s post-revolutionary military government ended subsidies for cotton farmers to shore up the state budget. A gradual decline in output has become a precipitous plunge. The US Department of Agriculture estimates there will be a 53 percent decrease in production this year, to an all-time low of 160 000 bales. The system for certifying Egyptian cotton is administered from Cairo by the Cotton Egypt Association, an industry group that grants stamps of approval to suppliers of 100-percent Egyptian cotton products. To receive one, CEA executive director Khaled Schuman explained, a manufacturer pays an initial fee of $5,000 and submits records of Egyptian cotton purchases and product samples, which undergo DNA analysis to identify whether the fibres were grown in Egypt or elsewhere. The companies are charged an additional $3 000 annually for the certification, according to Schuman. No supervision But once a certification is granted, producers are mostly left alone until they need to renew their label a year later. “You can’t put an employee from the association on each production line to inspect” every item being produced, said Mohamed Negm, who conducts testing of certification samples for the association to verify the fibres are Egyptian-grown. Typically, suppliers like Welspun purchase cotton in raw form from Egypt for import to Asia, where it’s turned into finished products for sale in the US and elsewhere, he said. The highest-quality Egyptian material costs twice as much as the standard grade sourced from India, providing a powerful incentive to cheat. “Factories have mixed the Egyptian cotton with other low quality cottons to make profit, which has ruined the reputation of Egyptian cotton,” said Negm, adding that’s what the DNA testing and certification aim to curtail. During the set-up of the CEA’s DNA testing program, Negm said, it started analysing random samples taken from store shelves globally; 90 percent were fake, mixed with low-quality cottons from the likes of Sudan, Burkina Faso and Pakistan. “It’s very easy to play it loose during the production process if you want,” said Liu Dang Dang, a foreign sales manager at Chinese manufacturer Jihua 3542 Textile US retailers “should have realised how obvious it is,” he said, adding that the company, which supplies Egyptian cotton fabric to manufacturers in the US and Europe, doesn’t engage in the practice. “The price they want to pay for Egyptian cotton sheets is so low when the price of Egyptian cotton is so high.” Widespread blending Blending is widespread in the industry and quietly tolerated by many retail chains, according to two executives at producers other than Welspun who asked not to be identified discussing the procedure. Sometimes that means mixing good-quality non-Egyptian cotton that maintains the same feel amid shortages of the real thing, but it also often includes using cheaper grades to save money, said the people, citing their experience with cotton processing departments and export requirements for US retailers. The CEA formally announced its DNA testing program in April, saying the “gold seal” it would give manufacturers who passed would help “rid the supply chain of falsely labelled goods.” Awkwardly, the first company to receive a gold seal was Welspun, for bed linens as well as towels and bath rugs. Target has decided not to rely on CEA certifications going forward, according to a person familiar with the retailer’s decisions who asked not to be identified discussing internal matters. Wal-Mart, by contrast, has said it will continue to rely on the CEA standard. Schuman said the organisation is “making good efforts to make the system tougher” to avoid future problems, for example by increasing the role of third-party auditors and monitoring suppliers’ inventories more closely. After discovering problems with Welspun sheets, Target quickly decided to terminate its entire relationship with the company, citing “the trust that our guests place in us.” It also opted to offer refunds to customers who’d purchased them -- even if they’d been sleeping on them for years. Wal-Mart has also offered refunds. Although Welspun knew Target was investigating its products, its executives believed that, at worst, the retailer would drop only its Egyptian cotton sheets, according to a person privy to the discussions. Target didn’t warn Welspun beforehand about its August. 19 announcement that it was ending all its business ties, the person said, which left the company blindsided. At the time chairman Goenka’s wife Dipali, who leads Welspun’s home textile business, had just returned to India from meetings in the U.S.; she turned around immediately to do damage-control with clients, according to a person familiar with the events. In Mumbai, her husband had called an emergency meeting of department heads. He told them to ignore the company’s plunging share price and to focus on their day jobs, and that Welspun would bounce back over time, the person said. Both Goenkas declined to be interviewed. Welspun, which has said the issue never affected the quality or safety of its products, hired the audit firm EY to evaluate its practices and supply chain. The company reports quarterly earnings Tuesday. The scandal is creating an opportunity for rival Indian supplier Trident, which has picked up a significant chunk of Welspun’s business from Wal-Mart, Target and Ikea, said a person familiar with the situation, who asked not to be identified because the information is private. Welspun is still a supplier for Ikea, according to a spokesperson for the Swedish company, adding that it does not buy products made from Egyptian cotton due to sustainability concerns. The company did not respond to a query on whether it’s awarded contracts to Trident. Chinese textile producers may also benefit, analysts said. Big US retailers tend to “go for Indian companies because they are cheaper,” particularly thanks to lower labor costs, said Jack Yang, an executive at Chinese manufacturer Yantai Pacific Home Fashion. Scarce cotton Anyone trying to capitalise, though, faces the same problem: a shortage of Egyptian cotton. That, in turn, might assist U.S. manufacturers of Pima cotton, another high-quality grade that promotes itself as a rival to the Egyptian variety. Back in Cairo, the guardians of the country’s sole global brand argue their efforts will be enough to rein in fakes, and they say the controversy might even have a silver lining. “If what was happening had continued, in a few years there would be zero Egyptian cotton,” Schuman said. “The turbulence now is positive. It’s raising awareness, and we are doing everything we can to protect the value of our product.” BLOOMBERG International Fedusa's new head to fight for fair wages for all Recommended National Minimum Wage set at R20 per hour SA to pursue decent standard of living for all Time abroad can crystallise career ideas Certainty, growth key in credit grade Most Read Union joins ‘Zuma must go’ chorus Junk rating inevitable for SA? Dis-Chem worth R20bn on debut Rand shivers as dollar makes broad gains India’s cash crisis hits SA tourists Advertisement MORE business internationalMenu News| Personal Finance| Budget| Companies| Startups| Markets| Indicators| International| Opinion| Leadership| Financial tools| Savings| WEF| business internationalMenu News| Personal Finance| Budget| Companies| Startups| Markets| Indicators| International| Opinion| Leadership| Financial tools| Savings| WEF| INFO About IOL Front page Market indicators Movie guide Newspapers TV guide Weather SITES BabyNet.co.za Glamour.co.za GQ.co.za Ilisolezwe Isolezwe IOL Jobs IOL Property IOL Sportzone Loot.co.za Classifieds WomanOnline SECTIONS News Business Sport Motoring Tonight Lifestyle Travel Scitech About IOL Front page Market indicators Movie guide Newspapers TV guide Weather

Warren Buffett is steadily unloading a massive position in Wal-Mart shares, and a big reason for his decision may be the ongoing shift to online shopping. Todd Campbell (TMFEBCapital) Nov 19, 2016 at 7:21AM Wal-Mart Stores (NYSE:WMT) has been a staple holding in Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRK-B)(NYSE:BRK-A) portfolio for years, but the Oracle of Omaha has soured on Wal-Mart's stock this year, and a new report from the U.S. Census Bureau showing that consumers continue to embrace e-commerce may mean that there's a good chance that Wal-Mart's completely out of Berkshire's portfolio by the end of this year.  IMAGE SOURCE: WAL-MART STORES. What's up? Wal-Mart may be a retail store Goliath, but it's far from the biggest online retailer, and that's a big problem for the company's future growth.. Wal-Mart's sales barely budged in the third quarter, increasing by a only a modest 0.5% from the third quarter of 2015. Meanwhile, consumers ongoing shift to online shopping propelled sales at online giant Amazon.com (NASDAQ:AMZN) 29% higher when compared to a year ago. According to the Census Bureau, that trend away from retail stores to online stores isn't losing steam. In Q3, U.S. retail e-commerce sales, adjusted for seasonal variation but not for price changes, grew 4% quarter over quarter to $101.3 billion. That handily outpaced the 0.9% quarter-over-quarter increase in total retail sales in the period, but the gap between the two is even wider when considering the year-over-year change. Compared to Q3 2015, adjusted e-commerce sales grew 15.7% last quarter, while total retail sales only grew 2.2%. Overall, the rapid growth in online purchases has led to e-commerce sales now accounting for 8.4% of total sales, up from 7.4% of sales a year ago. Growth in online shopping has been a boon to Wal-Mart competitors, especially Amazon. Online retailers have more inventory and marketing flexibility, and they also have cost advantages that help them compete better for wallet share. Trailing-12-month SG&A as a percentage of sales is more than 1% lower at Amazon than it is at Wal-Mart, and Amazon's gross profit margin is nearly 10% better than Wal-Mart's. AMZN gross profit margin (TTM) data by YCharts. Given that it's most likely that more consumer spending will migrate away from traditional stores to the internet, it's little wonder that investors like Buffett might be worrying more about Wal-Mart's future sales and profit headwinds. A tough competitor Earlier this year, Buffett praised Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, calling him a "genius." And at Berkshire Hathaway's annual investor event in Omaha, Buffett remarked, "We're not going to out-Bezos Bezos." In the past, Buffett was slow to embrace the use of the internet to boost sales at Berkshire Hathaway's wholly owned companies. However, that's recently been changing, and as he sees the sales tailwinds at his companies from his online initiatives, it may be factoring into his increasing admiration of Bezos, and his declining interest in owning bricks-and-mortar companies like Wal-Mart. It's probably not lost on Buffett that Amazon has been a much better investment than Wal-Mart over the years, either. Under Bezos' leadership, Amazon's trailing-12-month revenue has surged to $128 billion since 1994, and that's resulted in astonishing returns for long-term investors. Over the past 15 years, Amazon's 34%-per-year average return crushes the average 12.9% return for the specialty retail industry, and it absolutely demolishes Wal-Mart's 3.2% annual return over the period. Since Bezos doesn't appear ready to quit anytime soon, and e-commerce still represents less than 10% of total retail spending, it seems Wal-Mart's going to have its hands full for a long time if its going to attempt to keep Amazon at bay. Looking forward Buffett's sold tens of millions of shares in Wal-Mart this year, but he still has 12.9 million shares left in Berkshire Hathaway's portfolio. With Wal-Mart shares up 19% this year, he appears to see this as a great opportunity to "sell high" a business that could face increasingly more downside profit pressure in the coming years. Whether Buffett does sell his remaining Wal-Mart shares this year won't be known until early next year, when Berkshire Hathaway files its fourth-quarter 13F report with the Securities and Exchange Commission. But given his admiration for Bezos and his selling of 27.2 million Wal-Mart shares last quarter, I will not be surprised if Wal-Mart disappears from Berkshire's list of holdings.  Todd Campbell has no position in any stocks mentioned. Todd owns E.B. Capital Markets, LLC. E.B. Capital's clients may have positions in the companies mentioned. Like this article? Follow him on Twitter where he goes by the handle @ebcapital to see more articles like this. The Motley Fool owns shares of and recommends Amazon.com and Berkshire Hathaway (B shares). Try any of our Foolish newsletter services free for 30 days. We Fools may not all hold the same opinions, but we all believe that considering a diverse range of insights makes us better investors. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy. Author Todd Campbell (TMFEBCapital) Todd has been helping buy side portfolio managers as an independent researcher for over a decade. In 2003, Todd founded E.B. Capital Markets, LLC, a research firm providing action oriented ideas to professional investors. Todd has provided insight to a variety of publications, including SmartMoney, Barron's, and CNN/fn. Center Widget App in the Notification Center it makes using your iPhone or iPad. Quick show calendar. Download Center Widget VigTask Normally $0.99. VigTask – Smart organizer for your tasks! INTUITIVE INTERFACE • Many kinds of skins. • Data can be viewed as list or folders. • Clean looking and easy to understand. • Minimal of taps to enter your data. • Easy to complete task with one click. Recover your password Home Our Team Contact Us Black Friday Magazine Get the best Black Friday Alerts Before Anyone Else Home Deals Best Buy The 5 Hottest Thanksgiving Day Sales Deals Best Buy Sales Black Friday Kmart Target Walmart The 5 Hottest Thanksgiving Day Sales By Linda Cauthen - November 19, 2016 75 0 SHARE Facebook Twitter Even if you flatly refuse to tear yourself away from the family Turkey Day feast, you can still score some pretty cool deals this Thursday. Many retailers that will be opening their stores on Thanksgiving will also offer the same or comparable Doorbuster Deals online. Here are five chains offering deals worth checking out on Thanksgiving. Walmart OK, your local Superstore may be the last place you want to be on Thanksgiving Day, when Walmart will opens at 6 p.m. but the online deals start even earlier – at 12 a.m. Thursday morning. That means you can score a great deal on electronics while stuffing the turkey and never have to risk getting into a fist fight over the last big-screen TV in the store. Some of the better deals include a 55” Phillips Class Smart 4K TV for $298, a Roku Espress Plus for $25 and a Samsung Chromebook 3 for $119. Best Buy This retail chain promises “thousands of deals” for Black Friday but 16 of the most tempting are available online now so you don’t have to wait for stores to open at 5 p.m. on Thanksgiving. The online action starts at 12 a.m. and Best Buy is holding out these Doorbusters for the big day: a Toshiba 49” 4K Ultra HDTV for $199.99, the Amazon 16GB Fire Tablet for $59.99 and Powerbeats2 Wireless Headphones for $89.99. Kohl’s The best thing about Kohl’s Black Friday sale is that it starts on Monday, November 21 and runs until 1 p.m. on Friday. The in-store sale begins at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving. Hot items available online Monday include a Haier 49” 4K Ultra HDTV plus $75 in Kohl’s Cash for $349.99, a Fitbit Alta special edition fitness band for $99.99 and 50% off name brand toys. Target The Thanksgiving fun starts at 6 p.m. in-stores and online for Target but there are several hot deals available now and until November 24. These include a Samsung 55” 4K Motion Rate 120 Curved Smart Ultra HDTV with a free $75 Target gift card for $697.99, an XBox One S console bundle with free $40 Target gift card for $249.99 and 50% off life-sized figurine toys including Star Wars. KMart The deals aren’t very exciting at this discount retailer but it’s going to be the place to outfit the family for winter and the house for the holidays. Kmart opens for Thanksgiving in-store and online at 7 p.m. with a BOGO deal on family footwear, 50% off Christmas supplies and select DVDs and Blu-rays for $1 each. “Thanksgiving Night Doorbusters” will be good from the time stores open until 2 p.m. on Black Friday. Election didn't change our shopping habits 'We remain optimistic,' Target CEO says Video Photo College senior Alison Catalano is all smiles after finding the bed spread she'd been looking for at the Lake Zurich Target store on Thursday, Aug. 11, 2016 in Lake Zurich, Ill. Catalano was out shopping for furnishings for her 1st apartment as she goes into her senior year at St. Mary's of Notre Dame in South Bend. She is studying art education. (Stacey Wescott/Chicago Tribune) Washington Post Nov 18, 2016 at 4:40 pm | Print View The presidential election results may have changed a great many things: Your dinner table conversations, for example, and the kinds of posts in your Facebook feed. But executives at major retailers say they’re betting that the political climate will do little to alter your shopping habits this holiday season. “We haven’t really seen any noticeable change in sentiment in our customers,” said Greg Foran, Wal-Mart’s U.S. chief executive, on a Thursday conference call when asked whether the election would have an effect on the business. Foran’s comments echo what Brian Cornell, the chief executive of Target, said Wednesday when asked a similar question. “We remain very optimistic about the holiday season,” Cornell said, referring to economic factors such as a low unemployment rate. Both retailers reported relatively upbeat earnings results this week, adding to evidence that the retail industry is headed into the holiday shopping season with a tail wind. In its U.S. division, Wal-Mart saw a 1.2 percent increase in comparable sales, a measure of sales online and at stores open more than a year. The uptick came as the retailer did a better job of keeping store shelves well-stocked, and as its online sales heated up. This time around, e-commerce accounted for a greater share of the growth on this metric than in any previous quarter. Target reported improvement on some key measures: Foot traffic to its stores grew in the most recent quarter, and strong sales during the busy back-to-school shopping season helped narrow its decline in comparable sales. The retailer said it also has benefited from a recent change to its marketing tactics, in which it has moved to put a bigger spotlight on value and low prices. Macy’s and Kohl’s also reported stronger-than-expected earnings results last week. And the Commerce Department said Tuesday that retail sales were up 0.8 percent in October, a robust showing that suggests consumers are feeling relatively confident. Friday, November 18, 2016 Share this Email, Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn Discuss 5 comments Advertisement What does “Make America Great Again” really mean? MAGA was the slogan of the Donald Trump campaign. It was both inspirational and vague enough that citizens could project their individual ideas, hopes and dreams into it, much as citizens projected into Barack Obama's slogan “Yes We Can.” The Obama administration successfully met some aspirations and failed with others. The Trump administration? Time will tell. It looks like big chunks of the Trump coalition were looking for dramatic change, just as Bernie Sanders supporters were doing. The status quo simply wasn't tenable, not for people who'd grown up in the middle class, thanks to good-paying manufacturing jobs for their parents. Many of those jobs went away, across the border or overseas, leaving Mom and Dad working at Walmart or McDonald's and the kids struggling with college debt or camped out in the basement working minimum-wage jobs. There was tremendous anger at the establishment that allowed or encouraged the exodus of jobs in the name of free trade and globalization. Republicans were basically cheerleaders of the exodus because it made CEOs and investors richer. Democrats, those who weren't enablers of the exodus in the name of free trade, were ineffectual at stopping or even slowing the exodus of jobs. Retraining for guys who used to make $80,000 a year working the lines in Detroit, just so they could maybe make $30,000 a year in a service industry, just doesn't cut it. Then there was the role of retail giant Walmart, which not only destroyed Mom 'n Pop retail businesses on Main Street but also forced manufacturers to move factories to low-wage countries. (See Rubber Maid's well-documented experience with Walmart.) Reagan's assault on unions broke the link between ever-greater labor productivity with ever-better pay. NAFTA helped shatter the American Dream for millions. I suppose that if I could project my hopes onto MAGA, I'd opt for the Eisenhower era, when we had a booming and prosperous economy dominated by manufacturing. We built the inter-state, schools and suburbia for blue-collar families that enjoyed a social contract with owners/managers — I'll work hard and you'll provide a job for life and real hope for my kids. (Of course, all that was predicated on strong unions that had fought and bled for that prosperity, and a 92 percent highest tax rate on the 1 percent that paid off the costs incurred from the Great Depression and World War II. It was also predicated on the fact that the industrial world, save the US, was just emerging from the ruins of that war.) Did you know that right now, there's a prosperous, Western, liberal, capitalist country that has a robust economy dominated by manufacturing, one that has never shipped jobs and factories overseas? Germany copied our best management practices after the war. Labor unions are strong and work closely with management/owners. Germany enjoys trade surpluses with the rest of the world. Jobs are kept at home and immigration provides a labor supply as birth rates decline. As a result, blue-collar Germans enjoy excellent pay and benefits and virtually lifelong employment. German factories are opened overseas, not to replace shuttered factories at home but to expand market share abroad. And German CEOs don't make 300 to 400 times what a worker on the line makes. More like 30 times, so Germany doesn't have a 1 percent that dominates politics with campaign contributions, like our own Koch brothers. So why can't we be more like Germany? What do you want MAGA to mean? Sincerely, Brodie Farquhar Hayden More like this story Melanie Sturm: Trump, Sanders and Rorschach elections Melanie Sturm: The Trump tower that Obama built Hayden to fill council vacancy Donald Trump Jr. revs crowd in Grand Junction Thursday night Brodie Farquhar: What's going on down under? Comments Ken Mauldin 1 day, 20 hours ago In response to Brodie's question: What do you want MAGA to mean? As a starting point, for our citizens to return to the practice of engaging in a respectful, spirited debate of ideas without insults and name-calling. Upvote 2 Post reply Please Login and/or Verify your account to reply Sign in to suggest removal Chris Hadlock 1 day, 16 hours ago Our leaders too Ken. I support you in this. Upvote 0 Post reply Please Login and/or Verify your account to reply Sign in to suggest removal George Fargo 1 day, 18 hours ago America is Great already. MAGA is just a slogan Trumpy used to rile up the gullible. The world is moving forward. Technology is moving so fast that workers can't keep up with the jobs needed. In the words of the Prophet: "Them steady jobs are goin' forth and they ain't comin' back". Back to the 50s? Are you kidding? Upvote 1 Post reply Please Login and/or Verify your account to reply Sign in to suggest removal John Weibel 23 hours, 55 minutes ago Well, maybe looking at our tax structure, which is based on employment, not production. Maybe, as opposed to taxing labor, we restructure how the system works and tax goods sold. That way, products are not made to be disposable, taxes on goods sold does not replace the displacement of labor in favor of technology and many other things the fair tax would help solve, versus the current system that really works against human labor being employed in this country - in favor of technology or outsourcing. Upvote 0 Post reply Please Login and/or Verify your account to reply Sign in to suggest removal Scott Wedel 18 hours, 53 minutes ago John, If you change to taxing goods sold and not labor then that gives an even bigger advantage to large vertically integrated companies that can take raw materials into finished products. Small parts manufacturers then face taxes trying to supply another manufacturer. It makes more sense to tax labor as the job exists and the labor is being paid because something useful is being done. Otherwise, trying to tax the "goods" of knowledge jobs becomes arbitrary. The 50s were great for the US because most of the world's major economies were rebuilding what had been destroyed. That isn't going to happen again. With Obama in Peru there are articles on trade and the future of trade agreements with the USA. There is a certain level of "it doesn't matter" in Peru because they will export to China or whomever is willing to sign a bilateral trade deal. USA won't have additional jobs if we don't import artichokes grown in the opposite season as in the USA. What Germany has been doing well is connecting their education system to companies so that students are trained for the available jobs. USA has all sorts of openings for various skilled jobs, but lacks the qualified people to take those jobs. We have a trillion dollars in student debt and yet a shortage college graduates qualified to fill good paying skilled jobs. Upvote 0 Post reply Please Login and/or Verify your account to reply Sign in to suggest removal Requires free registration Posting comments requires a free account and verification. Subscribe for $59/Yr - Save $50 Apple Delivers New Macbook Pro Ad Amid Criticism of New Model By Rebecca Hia. Published on November 18, 2016. The New Macbook Pro ad that aired Thursday night. Credit: Apple Most Popular Every weekday, we bring you the Ad Age/iSpot Hot Spots, new and trending TV commercials tracked by iSpot.tv, a company that catalogs, tags and measures activity around TV ads in real time. The New Releases here ran on TV for the first time yesterday. The Most Engaging ads are showing sustained social heat, ranked by SpotShare scores reflecting the percent of digital activity associated with each one over the past week. Among the new releases, Old Navy promotes its Black Friday sale in a funny commercial featuring Amy Schumer, Walmart urges shoppers to "Get Up Offa That Thing" a la James Brown to check out its Black Friday sales as well, Starbucks features one of its baristas customizing red holiday cups with personalized messages and Taco Bell advertises its Steakhouse Burrito and Nachos, bemoaning the new fate of the once popular parsley accompaniment in a humorous commerical. Finally, Apple, shows how innovative ideas push our world forward, like the new Macbook Pro, despite criticism of its latest model. eBay Black Friday and Cyber Monday deals loaded with laptops, TVs and drones The online auction giant has a long list of "eBay Approved" deals including the Apple iPad Pro tablet, DJI drones and Xbox One and Playstation 4 bundles. eBay Black Friday and Cyber Monday deals loaded with laptops, TVs and drones 0 Laptops by Joshua Goldman November 18, 2016 9:53 AM PST @ByJoshG Up Next Trump presidency fuels heated encryption debate DJI's Phantom 4 will be $899 on eBay for Black Friday.Photo by Joshua Goldman/CNET While it seems every year Best Buy, Target, Walmart and Amazon get all the attention on Black Friday, sites like eBay have plenty of deals, too. As Black Friday approaches, eBay will have a countdown clock to let you know about the latest offers. As always, some deals are better than others, so check out all the Black Friday/Cyber Monday deals just to be sure you're getting the lowest possible price. Wal-Mart could give Amazon a run for its money this holiday season MarketWatch 2 days ago Tonya Garcia Click to expand Replay Video New figures show bad news for Wells Fargo Embattled bank Wells Fargo announced this week that new account openings fell by 44 percent in the month October and new credit card applications have fallen by over 50 percent. New figures released show that foot traffic to branches is also down, with "branch banker interactions" down 22 percent from 2015. The figures come in the wake of a sales practice scandal that triggered multiple lawsuits, an enormous $185 million fine and the resignation of the company's longtime CEO John Stumpf. Wochit Business Amazon's new ad: A response to anti-Muslim rhetoric Amazon's latest commercial targets anti-Muslim rhetoric by highlighting commonalities between a priest and an imam. CNN Money 'Amityville Horror' house sells for $850,000 The house that inspired the 1979 horror film “The Amityville Horror” has reportedly been sold after a listing of $850,00. The 5,000 square-foot home, which was built in 1927, boasts five bedrooms, three-and-a-half bathrooms, a boathouse and a slip and supposedly, plenty of demons. According to real estate site Redfin, the seller bought the property back in 2010 for $950,000, way below the asking price $1.15 million. Wochit News PlayPause Seek i VolumeVolume VolumeMuteUnmute CC SETTINGS OFF HQ HD HQ SD LOFull ScreenExit Full Screen PlayPause VolumeVolume Wal-Mart's Third-Quarter Results and Business Plan Bloomberg See more videos SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL What to watch next New figures show bad news for Wells Fargo Wochit Business0:51 Amazon's new ad: A response to anti-Muslim rhetoric CNN Money1:03 'Amityville Horror' house sells for $850,000 Wochit News0:45 One man in Georgia might have been inflating chicken prices nationwide Newsy1:07 Lego opens its biggest store in the world in London The Wall Street Journal.1:08 5 tips to help you save this holiday season Entrepreneur2:46 Trump says he helped keep Ford plant from moving CNBC0:38 McDonald's CEO: We are modernizing your burger experience CNN Money3:13 Volkswagen shedding 30,000 jobs Wochit Business0:39 How Trump's policies will impact IPOs Bloomberg3:28 Yellen on Dodd-Frank: 'I wouldn't want to see the clock turned back' CNN Money2:36 Couple’s guide to collecting Social Security CNBC1:43 Alaska's pot businesses must pay taxes in cash Wochit Business0:43 Trump rode $5 billion in free media to the White House The Street0:59 South Africa game industry counts drought costs Reuters1:42 Trump's family matters: Mixing business, government Bloomberg2:38 UP NEXT Wal-Mart Stores Inc. is reaping the rewards of its digital investments, which could position it as a force to be reckoned with in the online battle against the rest of the retail competition. Quotes in the article Wal-Mart Stores Inc WMT ▼ 68.54 -0.65 -0.94% SPX Corp SPXC ▲ 23.20 +0.29 +1.27% “For holiday and fourth quarter, we expect Walmart to continue to excel on multiple fronts, particularly online where we expect sales to continue to accelerate on a percentage basis, with a growth rate approaching 30% likely as it leverages its store network to handle online orders, especially via its buy online/pick-up in-store capability, as well as increasing benefits from Jet.com,” said Charlie O’Shea, lead retail analyst at Moody’s. Wal-Mart (WMT) reported a 20.6% increase in global e-commerce sales on a constant-currency basis for the third quarter. Moody’s puts Wal-Mart’s online sales growth on a base of $14 billion to $15 billion, without a full quarter of Jet.com results. Total revenue for the third quarter was $118.2 billion, up from $117.4 billion last year, but falling short of the FactSet consensus of $118.6 billion. Earnings per share were 98 cents, down from $1.03 last year, but ahead of the 96-cent FactSet estimate. =Wal-Mart added eight million SKUs (stock keeping units) to the website over the past three months, Chief Executive Doug McMillion said Thursday in his prepared remarks. And e-commerce added 50 basis points to the retailer’s third-quarter U.S. same-store sales figure, “which is our largest contribution yet,” he added. Walmart U.S. same-store sales increased 1.2% in the third quarter, driven by a 0.7% traffic increase, Wal-Mart said. Wal-Mart announced a strategic alliance with Chinese e-commerce company JD.com this summer, that included the sale of its Yihaodian website to JD.com. See also: Wal-Mart’s deal with China’s JD.com may be copied by others The partners announced that they were launching three new initiatives in late October. Wal-Mart has also invested in New Dada, a Chinese on-demand logistics and grocery e-commerce platform, McMillon said in his remarks. New Dada is making two-hour delivery service from 45 Walmart locations possible. Wal-Mart announced that it was acquiring Jet.com for $3 billion in August. Jet.com founder Marc Lore took over Wal-Mart’s e-commerce operations earlier this month.  Neil Saunders, chief executive of retail research agency and consulting firm Conlumino, believes Wal-Mart’s U.S. online growth “is now well above the overall market,” which indicates they’re adding share. But there are other factors playing a role in the result. “The figures include half a quarter of sales from recently acquired Jet.com, which flatters the results somewhat,” said Saunders in a note published Thursday. “Nonetheless, we believe that Walmart is now on much more positive trajectory in terms of both its e-commerce strategy and results.” Walmart's Strategy on Food Safety and Affordability Frank Yiannas, vice president of Food Safety at Walmart Stores, discusses the strategy for reducing risk and providing consumers with safe, affordable foods at America's largest grocery chain. He spoke with WSJ's Sarah Nassauer at the WSJ Global Food Forum in New York.  “We view the same-store sales growth as evidence that Wal-Mart’s investment in labor, e-commerce and marketing its value message are working,” said The Buckingham Research Group in a note published Thursday. “However, some investors may be disappointed that traffic and comps decelerated slightly from fiscal second-quarter 2016.” Wal-Mart highlighted food deflation, weather and currency impacts among the headwinds. Wal-Mart shares are up 11.8% for the year so far while the S&P 500 index (SPX) is up 6.7% for the same period. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) is up 8.3% for 2016 so far. KAST 1370 Events KAST Programming About KAST Local Personalities Tom Freel KAST Contacts Eagle Country 102.3 KCRX Clammy 99.7 106.3 The Beach About OMG OMG Astoria Contest Rules Game Day Giveaway Harvest Haul Warrenton Walmart Construction Underway Spring of 2018 the doors open on a new WalMart Supercenter in Warrenton’s North Coast Business Park. Construction of the new 154,400 SF store is under the supervision of one of the most prolific and respected construction firms on the West Coast. Deacon Corp started in a tiny, borrowed office space in a small office building in southwest Portland in 1981. Steve Deacon and his wife were the company along with three friends. Since those early days Deacon Corp has grown to employ about 400 people who work out of offices in Seattle, Portland, Sacramento, Pleasanton and Irvine. According to the company website there is no headquarters and little in the way of hierarchy. The management structure seems to be working very well as Deacon has developed some iconic retail outlets over the years. Their project portfolio includes Portland’s flagship IKEA store, Cascade Plaza just off Airport Way at PDX, Seattle Premium Outlets in Marysville, 200 Target stores along the West coast, REI stores and The Woodburn Outlet Mall, just to name a few. In 2013 Deacon was named the #1 retail contractors in California and that same year the Woodburn Outlet Mall honored Deacon with an outstanding service award. In the industry they are noted for being able to smoothly coordinate multiple sub-contractors to successfully complete projects from small to very large. As for the Warrenton project, there was a quiet groundbreaking held last week and crews started to work on site development. By Friday morning Deacon signs were posted and a large construction trailer appeared on the site. The beginnings of an access road was taking shape and containment systems and been installed along the Highway frontage. The detailed drawings of the project indicate the store will have a grocery section with a bakery and deli. Plans also call for a garden supply shop, pharmacy, vision center and a tire and car battery section. All this is according to the bid plans for the project. ©2016 Ohana Media Group EEOC

Square Blossoms Water Authority West Rock Trails Westville Renaissance Westville Synagogue What Now New Haven Workforce Alliance Yale Events YMCA Youth Continuum Three Peels For The Bus Driver! by Shari Hoffman | Nov 19, 2016 5:44 pm Post a Comment | E-mail the Author Posted to: Opinion, Transportation, The Heights, CT Bus Diaries, True Vote From about 5 p.m. on I was waiting at the New Haven Walmart for the bus to come. A bunch of us waiting were from Bella Vista. The driver was nearly 20 minutes late, and it was getting cold. That was the beginning of an adventure early Sunday evening. One gal waiting was becoming impatient. She was tempted, as I have been in the past, to get on a bus that goes to Universal Drive first before it comes back to Bella Vista (the D14 bus). We persuaded her to wait since this would have taken longer to get home. Finally our D5 came. We got on. One person was still waiting to get on; he was confined to a wheelchair. I didn’t know him. Some of the women I got on with were chatting away. I could hear one talking about the uses of banana peels. I wasn’t sitting close enough, so all I heard her say was that she got rid of a wart with banana peels.  I didn’t know what to think of that. All I could think about was wanting to get home after standing outside in the cold and the dark. Eventually I realized that the bus driver was on his phone for quite some time having a very serious conversation with CT Transit. We were not going anywhere. A man in a wheelchair was waiting to get on the bus. The doors to the bus were open, and we were still cold because of it. Eventually the bus driver got off the bus and stood outside with his hands in his pockets, not saying anything to any of us. All we knew was that we were not going anywhere, and we didn’t know why. Then I saw him on his cell phone. Frustrated, wanting to know what was happening, I got off the bus to find out. I waited until he hung up his cell and then walked over to him and asked him why we were not going anywhere. He said, “I heard a passenger say they have ‘ebola’ and we can’t go anywhere until this is taken care of.” “No one has ebola,” I said. “A woman was talking about banana peels.” “Ohhhhhhh,” he said “I thought someone was ill.” He looked confused and then said again he thought someone was ill. I reiterated that the woman was talking about helpful uses for banana peels and that no one had ebola. “Forget about this,” he said, still looking serious and a bit embarrassed. I got back on the bus, and everyone wanted to know what he said. “It’s not worth repeating,” I said. That made everyone push me to tell what transpired , so I said without using the name of the illness, “The bus driver thought he heard someone say they were sick, and that‘s why we‘re not going anywhere.” Now the passengers were more confused and asked for more information. Eventually I told them the full story. Everyone was laughing. Some decided that the driver was a germaphobe and crazy. We still had to wait for the bus driver’s supervisor to come. After she arrived, the two of them chatted for quite some time. Inside the bus and watching them, I once again wondered why it was still taking so long. So again I got off the bus and approached the two of them. The supervisor looked like a nice gal; none of this was her doing. I smiled at her. She smiled back. I started to ask if we could get going. As the words were on the tip of my tongue, they ended their conversation and started helping the man in the wheelchair onto the bus, which took another five minutes. This whole event must have taken about 45 minutes; plus, the bus was running 20 minutes late to start with. I finally got home with my banana-peel-informed neighbor from Bella Vista. As we got off the bus we were laughing about the whole circumstance but were mainly glad to be home. She told me that banana peel can even whiten your teeth.  I’ve never known a dentist to share this information, nor did I ever see banana peels advertised on TV as a teeth whitener. I had to Google it — and sure enough I found it! My neighbor was right — one can even shine their shoes with banana peels! I called the bus company Monday hoping for a report from the previous evening’s events. The operator I spoke with checked and said that there wasn’t any kind of information pertinent to the event I experienced. I asked her if it is typical that a report is filed when a supervisor has to come out. No there is not, she said. There is a report filed only when there is a complaint. I wish I had filed a complaint, because this was purely nutty and it held up a lot of people on a Sunday evening. Monday Evening’s Ride   At the end of the next day, Monday, I was waiting for a D bus at the stop on Chapel Street right after Foot Locker going toward Fair Haven. I get on at Chapel and State. I got in a D13 bus at the corner of Chapel and State (opposite Elm City Market) around 5:30 p.m.. The bus was packed. As I put my ticket in the fare box, I heard someone say the word “doo.” Then I saw people pointing to a completely empty seat.“You can’t sit there,” one said. “Someone went to the bathroom on the seat.” As I moved farther into the bus I smelled the “doo.” Some folks were holding their noses. It was gross. (I didn’t see any “doo,” though.) I didn’t know where I was going to sit. Then a kind woman motioned for me to sit on the inside of her seat. She was holding a spray bottle of cleaner and paper towels. How she knew to come prepared, I don’t know. I asked her what happened. She said someone had an accident on the seat … which I could smell, yet when I looked over at the seat there wasn‘t anything there except the smell that told the story. The windows of the bus were open. As we rode along, fresh air eventually cleared the smell out. When the gal with the paper towels next to me got off the bus, a young man from the back came over and sat down. I asked him if he knew what happened but he really didn’t know, either. He surmised that someone had an accident and got off the bus right afterwards. As I exited the bus, I tried one last time. I asked the driver if she knew what happened.  She looked weary and shook her head. Shari Hoffman lives at Bella Vista and regularly rides CT Transit buses. Tags: CT Transit Your Email: Subject: Message:

Black Friday fever: Your inside scoop on holiday shopping Patt Johnson , pjohnson@dmreg.com 6:20 p.m. CST November 19, 2016 Skip Ad Ad Loading... x Embed x Share Confused about where to shop for those Thanksgiving deals? Have no fear. We've put together a list for you. USA TODAY NETWORK Buy Photo Sarah Menzel (center) and mother, Denise Menzel, look through calendars Friday, Nov. 27, 2015, as they try to find Black Friday deals at Valley West Mall in West Des Moines. (Photo: Michael Zamora/The Register)Buy Photo Eager to put the election behind them, consumers are expected to spend with enthusiasm this holiday shopping season, with retailers expecting Thanksgiving and Black Friday sales to outpace previous years. "Influence from the election was a distraction," said Marshal Cohen, a retail analyst with New York-based NPD Group. "But now we see that half the country is happy and ready to get back to spending, while the other half is sad and in need of some retail therapy." Consumers are expected to spend an average of $935.58 each during the holiday shopping season, including $588.90 on gifts and $207.07 for items such as food, decorations, flowers and greeting cards, according to a National Retail Federation survey. They will spend the remaining $139.61 on themselves, the survey showed. Shoppers insistent on getting the best bargains will be out in force on Black Friday, said C. Britt Beemer, chairman of the consumer behavior marketing company America's Research Group. DES MOINES REGISTER Mall of America to close on Thanksgiving. Are Iowa malls next? In a recent telephone survey, Beemer found that 40 percent of people said they would be shopping on Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving, especially if there are door-buster deals and deep discounts advertised. Most people believe that “the only time to get the super deals is on the Black Friday holiday weekend,” he said. Shoppers already have been previewing Thanksgiving Day and Black Friday advertisements that have been published or leaked online. But most will pore over newspaper ads that come out the day before Thanksgiving, Beemer said. Overall, retail sales are expected to be up 2.5 percent this holiday season over last, Beemer predicted. Discount retailers likely will be the winners of the season, said Cohen. "Mass merchants like Target and Wal-Mart are in the right position because of their value, full assortment and early and aggressive promotions. Department stores are the most vulnerable," he said. Skip Ad Ad Loading... x Embed x Share Black Friday is no longer the only go-to option for finding the best deals. Here are the other big days to watch out for this holiday shopping season. USA TODAY NETWORK Here's what else you can expect for the holiday shopping season: Online shopping growing Perhaps eager to avoid the crowds, more shoppers are opting to buy their holiday gifts and other items online. For the first time, online spending will equal in-store shopping, according to the Deloitte Consulting holiday shopping survey. Two-thirds of shoppers said they will research items online and then buy them in a store, according to the Deloitte survey. About half said they planned to check out items in the stores and then shop for better prices online. Smartphones are helping people shop in greater numbers. Survey respondents said they will use their smartphones to locate stores, compare prices, read reviews, browse for items, get coupons, check for availability and make purchases, according to Deloitte. DES MOINES REGISTER Deals and duds in the search for Black Friday savings Filling out the ranks Retailers traditionally pump up their employment ranks during the holiday shopping season to handle the shopping onslaught. This year, companies such as Target, Kohl’s, Younkers and others are hiring about the same number of extra workers as last year. Delivery and mail-order companies such as United Parcel Service and Amazon are adding more jobs this season to help with increased online shopping. "The sector with the biggest increase in holiday hiring in recent years has been transportation and warehousing, as more and more holiday shopping is done online," John Challenger, chief executive officer of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, said in a statement. And while companies such as Target and BonTon Stores Inc. (parent company of Younkers) have held steady with their number of holiday workers in stores this year, they are adding more help in their distribution centers, Challenger said. You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 12 2 of 12 3 of 12 4 of 12 5 of 12 6 of 12 7 of 12 8 of 12 9 of 12 10 of 12 11 of 12 12 of 12 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show CaptionsLast SlideNext Slide Doing Black Friday right If you decide to let Thanksgiving be Thanksgiving and put off shopping until Black Friday, get an early start. Comb the ads and circulars for the best deals. Don’t forget online retailers, who also advertise deals. Here are some more tips from Consumer Reports: Shoppers can do comparison shopping on sites such as FatWallet, PriceGrabber.com, PriceWatch.com, Shopping.com, Google Shopping and NexTag.com. Retailers sometimes will have unique model numbers or product names, making direct price comparisons difficult. Retailers' loyalty programs can offer sales, coupons and discounts to members. Also, remember to check retailers’ social media sites, including Facebook and Twitter, to get notices of deals. Avoid overspending by creating a budget and sticking to it. Curb impulse buys and use cash to avoid credit cards. Skip Ad Ad Loading... x Embed x Share The online retailer plans to add deals every five minutes from now until December 22nd. Time Black Thursday, aka Thanksgiving Day Some retailers are closed Thanksgiving Day to give workers time to spend with their families. REI, the outdoor retailer, is going a step further and staying closed on Black Friday. Here’s a short list of stores open on Thanksgiving: Kmart will open at 6 a.m. Thursday. J.C. Penney: 3 p.m. Best Buy: 5 p.m. Wal-mart: 24-hour stores will not close for Thanksgiving. Target: 6 p.m. Younkers: 5 p.m. Toys R Us: 5 p.m. Old Navy: 4 p.m. Stores closed on Thanksgiving, many of which will open early for Black Friday: Von Maur, Bed Bath & Beyond, Dillard’s, Costco, TJ Maxx, Marshalls and The Container Store. You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 12 2 of 12 3 of 12 4 of 12 5 of 12 6 of 12 7 of 12 8 of 12 9 of 12 10 of 12 11 of 12 12 of 12 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show CaptionsLast SlideNext Slide Mall-ternatives Black Friday shoppers who have finished browsing the malls or who want to avoid them altogether can support local businesses by checking out some of the Small Business Saturday special events. Market Day Iowa is a one-day pop-up market featuring indie crafters and artists. This year's event will be held from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Black Friday in the atrium of Capital Square, 400 Locust St. in downtown Des Moines. About 65 local vendors will be selling their handmade wares. There also are shopping centers in the metro — including, the East Village and the Shops at Roosevelt, both in Des Moines; Valley Junction and West Glen Town Center in West Des Moines; and Uptown in Ankeny — that offer local retailers. You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 60 2 of 60 3 of 60 4 of 60 5 of 60 6 of 60 7 of 60 8 of 60 9 of 60 10 of 60 11 of 60 12 of 60 13 of 60 14 of 60 15 of 60 16 of 60 17 of 60 18 of 60 19 of 60 20 of 60 21 of 60 22 of 60 23 of 60 24 of 60 25 of 60 26 of 60 27 of 60 28 of 60 29 of 60 30 of 60 31 of 60 32 of 60 33 of 60 34 of 60 35 of 60 36 of 60 37 of 60 38 of 60 39 of 60 40 of 60 41 of 60 42 of 60 43 of 60 44 of 60 45 of 60 46 of 60 47 of 60 48 of 60 49 of 60 50 of 60 51 of 60 52 of 60 53 of 60 54 of 60 55 of 60 56 of 60 57 of 60 58 of 60 59 of 60 60 of 60 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show CaptionsLast SlideNext Slide Gift cards still a top seller Gift cards are still the go-to purchases for shoppers befuddled about filling out their gift lists. More than half of all consumers say at least some of the presents they plan to give this year will be gift cards, according to a survey from Bankrate, a consumer finance website. But only 27 percent of those surveyed preferred receiving a gift card over an actual gift at the holidays, according to Bankrate. The Iowa Attorney General's Office offers some tips on buying and using gift cards: Gift cards cannot expire for at least five years after the card purchase date, or from the last date a consumer added additional funds onto the card. The expiration date must be clearly disclosed on the card. The merchant or institution offering the card cannot charge inactivity fees until the card has not been used for at least a year, and can charge only one fee per month. All fees must be clearly disclosed on the package. Be wary of purchasing gift cards from online auction sites, because the cards may have been used or may be fraudulent. 8 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE Read or Share this story: http://dmreg.co/2g5Bg7J

"Following" : "Follow"}} November 18, 2016 11:18am   Comments Share: Related WMT Wal-Mart Remains Barclays' Top Pick Despite Mixed Results 5 Good Things And 4 Bad From Wal-Mart's Earnings Buffett Sold Most Of His Wal-Mart, Should You? (Seeking Alpha) Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE: WMT) reported Q3 results before market open on Thursday, and the shares ticked lower over the trading day. Rating And Price Target Looking past the retail giant’s mixed results and soft guidance, Baird Equity Research analyst Peter S. Benedict maintained both his Outperform rating for the retail giant and his $80 price target. Justification The analyst cited the following as key reasons behind his maintained rating: Tightly controlled inventory. An EPS in line with estimates. Accelerated e-commerce sales. “Respectable” comparables performance. Outlook. Wal-Mart saw global e-commerce sales up 20.6 percent, compared with Q2’s 11.8 percent increase and an “even stronger growth” in the United States, according to Benedict. “When combined with WMT's defensive appeal within a still choppy consumer/retail backdrop, we remain Outperform-rated,” said Benedict. At time of writing, Wal-Mart shares were trading at $68.72. Politics Smart Living Money Entertainment Health Tech Science Sports Video Contests Live Like Follow Lifestyle November 18, 2016 10:35 am Updated: November 18, 2016 3:31 pm Best Black Friday and Cyber Monday deals for 2016 By Katie Scott National Online Journalist, Smart Living & Entertainment  Global News ; A kitchen table full of "Black Friday" Sale Circulars with Sale Promotions from various Retailers. Getty Images What is this? Sponsored content is written by Global News' editorial staff without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... What is this ? X What is this? Sponsored content is written by Global News' without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... - A A + Listen Black Friday is almost upon us. For years, retailers have rolled out huge sales (and pre-Black Friday deals) in honour of the day after Americans celebrate their Thanksgiving. The tradition began in the United States, according to Snopes, because retailers wanted to capture the millions of consumers who get the day off (hello, holiday shopping!). But today, more and more countries are embracing the massive shopping event. WATCH: Black Friday chaos has crossed the pond as shoppers across the U.K. are fighting it out for door crasher deals with many of the moments caught on tape (Nov. 2014). It’s even extended into something called “Cyber Monday.” Think mega-deals online where limitless retailers reduce prices even further to clear out their stock. Instead of scrambling to search for the best deals around for pre-Black Friday, Black Friday and Cyber Monday, Global News has put together an all-encompassing list for you. (Keep an eye on this space since we’ll be updating the info every day.) Pre-Black Friday Sales Aldo Accessories: Seven daily deals for the week prior to Black Friday. Everyday there’s a different promotion in store and online. Check online for more info. Addition Elle: Black Friday week includes five days of deals starting on Nov. 20. AG Jeans: Enjoy 30 per cent off site-wide and in stores with code AGTHIRTY from Nov. 23 to 28. Excludes use of gift cards and purchases at AG outlet stores. Amazon.ca: During their “Countdown to Black Friday,” Amazon will roll out limited-time lightning deals every day. Aritzia: Enjoy 50 per cent off select fall/winter items site-wide and in stores from Nov. 22 to 24. No code required. Banana Republic: Enjoy 50 per cent off five regular-priced items for both women’s and men’s collections from Nov. 24 to 28, in stores and online with code BRFIVE. Best Buy: Save up to 30 per cent on major appliances with the Early Black Friday appliance sale on now. No code required. Huge SAVINGS on a massive selection of the best brands in appliances! "Following" : "Follow"}} November 18, 2016 8:34am   Comments Share: Related WMT Wal-Mart Remains Barclays' Top Pick Despite Mixed Results Wal-Mart's Soft Q4 Guidance Doesn't Rock Baird Analyst's Positive View Buffett Sold Most Of His Wal-Mart, Should You? (Seeking Alpha) Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE: WMT) reported an earnings beat for its fiscal third quarter of 2017. Although comps narrowly missed expectations, they “may have beat had it not been for unusually warm weather which hurt apparel and other sales,” Barclays’ Karen Short said in a report. She maintains an Overweight rating on the company, with a price target of $82. Wal-Mart reported its quarterly EPS at $0.98, versus Barclays’ estimate of $0.97. EPS benefited from a one-off gain and a lower tax rate. Short reduced the EPS estimates for Q4 and FY 2017 from $1.18 to $1.25 and from $4.33 to $4.27, respectively, citing lower comps and operating margin at Wal-Mart U.S., weaker international revenue and higher expenses. 5 Positives And 4 Negatives Short highlighted the positives from the quarter: Steady traffic growth at Wal-Mart U.S. A larger basket size driven by Fresh. A 32bps gross margin expansion at Wal-Mart U.S., despite tough comps and price investment. Accelerated in e-commerce GMV growth to 28.6 percent year-over-year. A 6 percent decline in Wal-Mart U.S. comp store inventory. The analyst's negatives: An expected slowdown in Wal-Mart U.S. comps in Q4. A 130bps rise in SG&A rate at Wal-Mart U.S. Weaker-than-expected operating income at Sam's Club. International segment facing continued currency headwinds. In Friday's pre-market session, Wal-Mart was up 0.13 percent at $69.28. AccuWeather.com Quick Look Change your current location » View Full Weather Report Search Search Search Cleveland.com Account Sign In Close Sign in to Cleveland.com You are signed in as Edit Public Profile Sign Out Subscribe The Plain Dealer Sun News Media Insider Rewards comments Black Friday 2016: 7 questions answered heading into the busiest shopping days of the year Black Friday shopping 2014 Kevin Weir waits to purchase his electronics inside the Best Buy store in Strongsville during Black Friday 2014. The National Retail Federation expects consumers to spend an average of $935.58 over the holidays this year, including gifts for others, self-gifting, food, flowers, decorations and greeting cards for Christmas, Hanukkah and Kwanzaa. That's second only to last year's all-time NRF record of $952.58. (Marvin Fong, Plain Dealer file) Print Email Janet H. Cho, The Plain Dealer By Janet H. Cho, The Plain Dealer The Plain Dealer Email the author | Follow on Twitter on November 18, 2016 at 8:36 AM, updated November 18, 2016 at 9:34 AM comments CLEVELAND, Ohio -- Retailers have spent months preparing for the coming week of shopping from Thanksgiving through Black Friday and Small Business Saturday, hoping that their clever promotions and carefully selected merchandise will be just the thing to draw eager shoppers into their stores and ready to spend. Some are hoping that consumers who were anxious about the presidential election will welcome the invitation to brighten other people's holidays with some retail therapy, and strengthen the economy heading into the new year. Q. Is Black Friday really the busiest shopping day of the year? A. Not always, but this year, it very well might be. ShopperTrak, the Chicago-based technology company that tracks foot traffic, buying patterns, and transaction size, says the top three shopping days for 2016 will be: Black Friday (Nov. 25), the Monday right after Christmas (Dec. 26), and the Friday before Christmas Eve (Dec. 23). "This year, we are dubbing Dec. 17 'Super Saturday' because we expect it to be the busiest Saturday of December," said Brian Field, ShopperTrak's senior director of advisory services, in a statement. "However, it will be no match for Black Friday, which will be the busiest shopping day of the holiday season."  ShopperTrak says Dec. 17 will be the fourth busiest shopping day of the year. On the other hand, Foursquare, which tracks more than 50 million mobile users a month as they trek to malls, boutiques and big-box stores, says Black Friday as a whole has been losing steam for years as people spread out their shopping over the entire holiday season. Foursquare expects Black Friday foot traffic will be down 3.5 percent from last year. Q. Why is it even called "Black Friday"? A. Traditionally, the Friday after Thanksgiving marked the beginning of the holiday shopping season, as well as when retailers that had been operating "in the red" started raking in profits, or running "in the black." Now, with mass merchandizers like Walmart announcing their lists of the hottest holiday toys as early as Sept. 1, the Christmas shopping season starts a lot earlier than it used to. After Walmart, rival Toys 'R' Us came out with its own #TRUhottoylist on Sept. 8. And while many retailers do make 25 percent to 45 percent of their annual sales in the final quarter, which includes Thanksgiving, Christmas, Hanukkah and Kwanzaa, if they actually had to wait until the end of November to become profitable, most of them wouldn't be able to stay open the rest of the year. Q. So why are so many stores opening their doors on Thanksgiving? A. Because Black Friday shoppers with fat wallets and long shopping lists tend to spend the most money at the first store they hit, retailers all compete to become that first stop, by opening their doors earlier and earlier.  In 2008, Kohl's and JCPenney opened at 4 a.m. to get a jump on the stores that opened at 5 a.m. and 6 a.m. By 2013, many stores were open at 8 p.m. on Thanksgiving, and this year, JCPenney is opening at 3 p.m. Thanksgiving Day.  ShopperTrak and other retail observers are skeptical that opening on Thanksgiving is worth the cost of opening that day. The Mall of America in Bloomington, Minnesota, the nation's largest shopping center with more than 520 stores and restaurants, made headlines when it announced on Oct. 5 that it would stay closed this Thanksgiving. "Based on our findings, it's clear that Thanksgiving Day openings may risk more in operating costs than in expanding sales opportunities," Field. "Not to mention, opening on Thanksgiving has serious implications on staff morale." Locally, both Beachwood Place Mall and Ohio Station Outlets in Lodi are staying closed for Thanksgiving, although individual stores might open early. Q. But are the deals really worth camping out for? A. Depends on what you think of what's being offered. Retailers try to tempt early shoppers by offering them the biggest discounts on limited quantity big-ticket items, such as appliances, jewelry and flat-screen TVs, and by giving extra goodies to the first ones in line. NerdWallet, a personal finance website out of San Francisco, said that when it compared the promotions from Black Friday 2016 to 2015, it found that many major retailers like JCPenney, Best Buy, and Kohl's do offer lower prices on Thanksgiving and Black Friday than they do the rest of the holiday season.  On the other hand, NerdWallet said, it noticed that at least 32 retailers are repeating at least one Black Friday deal from 2015. Ohio Station Outlets in Lodi is giving the first 200 shoppers at its guest services office at 6 a.m. on Black Friday a $15 gift certificate redeemable at any outlet store. Plus, it is giving away Roku Express streaming media players to the first 100 shoppers with $275 or more in same-day receipts. Q. What kinds of stores do well on Black Friday? A. Foursquare says online and in-store promotions, warmer-than-usual temperatures, and how people feel about the election all factor into shopping decisions, but it expects the number of shoppers hitting big-box stores to increase 5 percent this year. Columbus-based "Big Lots will see the largest spike in the big-box category on Black Friday 2016, and Dollar Tree will be the leaders for the discount category -- with gains that will be even more pronounced closer to Christmas," Foursquare said in a written announcement. Among department stores, it predicts Marshall's, Dillard's and Macy's will see the largest increase in foot traffic. Q. What about Small Business Saturday? A. Mass merchandisers and discount stores with large advertising budgets do have an edge over small retailers on Black Friday, but American Express and local businesses are hoping consumers will still eat and shop locally on Small Business Saturday and beyond. The Merchants of Hudson, which includes more than 90 shops and restaurants, is holding a Celebration of Lights and Caroling from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. on Black Friday. And the nonprofit Ten Thousand Villages in Cleveland Heights, which sells fair-trade crafts and gifts made by artisans in developing countries, is welcoming a cash mob of local shoppers who have pledged to spend at least $20 each, from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Nov. 19. Q. What are retailers expecting this holiday shopping season? A. Retailers are always optimistic about holiday spending. The National Retail Federation expects consumers to spend an average of $935.58 over the holidays, according to surveys conducted by Prosper Insights. That amount, which includes gifts for others, self-gifting, food, flowers, decorations and greeting cards for Christmas, Hanukkah and Kwanzaa, is second only to last year's all-time NRF record of $952.58. NRF says holiday spending over November and December is supposed to increase 3.6 percent to $655.8 billion. That includes a 7 percent to 10 percent spike in online sales, up to $117 billion. Some retail experts said uncertainty about the presidential election was making consumers more cautious, but it's unclear if the prospect of President-Elect Donald Trump will make people spend more or less this December. Perhaps that's why nearly six in 10 shoppers NRF surveyed said they were planning to splurge on themselves, spending an average of $139.61 on self indulgences, 4 percent more than last year. (WMT) Dipped After Q3 Profit Fell 11/18/2016 7:40 AM ET Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT) reported third quarter EPS of $0.98 Thursday morning, down from $1.03 in the prior year period. Total revenue for was $118.18 billion, an increase of 0.7% from $117.41 billion last year. The consensus estimates were for EPS of $0.96 and revenues of $118.69 billion. The company now expects to report full year 2017 adjusted EPS of $4.20 to $4.35, compared to prior expectations of $4.15 to $4.35. The consensus estimate is for EPS of $4.34. Wal-Mart gapped open lower Thursday and slipped further in early trade. The stock settled into a range for the bulk of the session and closed down by 2.20 at $69.19 on the highest volume in 3 months. Wal-Mart fell to over a 1-week low and slipped beneath its 50 and 200-day moving averages. by RTT Staff Writer For comments and feedback: editorial@rttnews.com Business News Preview: Thanksgiving Week Economic Data Top Ten Corporate Comeback Stories The Most Influential Books In Business Next Story Before the bell Cisco Systems Inc. Top 2016 Black Friday Deals on Razor, Swagtron and Jetson Hoverboards Posted on November 17, 2016 Tweet Hoverboards and electric scooters are another spotlighted item in Black Friday ads this year. The best deal is from Walmart. They will have the Razor Hovertrax 2.0 for $273, over $20 less than the next closest price. The Walmart Hovertrax Black Friday deal is pictured above. Kmart, Target, Kohl's and Toys R Us are among other retailers listing hoverboards in their Black Friday ads. The top current names in hoverboards are the Jetson V6 (sold exclusively at Target), the Razor Hovertrax and Swagtron. Regular prices for recently released hoverboard models can range from $349 to $399. Here is a list of some of the top deals: Jetson V6 w/Bluetooth Speakers - $284.99 (Target) Swagtron T1 - $299.99 (BJ's) Swagtron T1 + $50 Gift Card - $349.99 (Fred Meyer) Swagtron T5 - $199.99 (Toys R Us) Razor E100 - $119.99 (Kmart) Razor E175 - $94 (Target) Razor Hovertrax 2.0 - $273 (Walmart) Razor Hovertrax 2.0 - $299.99 (Academy Sports) Razor Hovertrax 2.0 - $299.99 (Shopko) Razor Hovertrax 2.0 - $349.99 (Kohl's) Razor Power Core E90 - $89.99 (Meijer) Razor Power Core E90 - $99.99 (Kohl's) Segway MiniPro - $99 (Sam's Club) You can find Walmart's Razor Hovertrax 2.0 listing here. The deal will be available starting Thanksgiving Day. Be sure to also check Amazon's deals on Hovertrax and other electric scooters.
